  2633. I wish they were a little easier to keep clean, but they are better than other electric brushes I have owned in the past.
  2634. There is a battery indicator light that I check each time I brush, and it has stayed solid green (it blinks when it's low) for nearly three weeks
  2635. The clean you feel after using this brush is unbelievable, IMO.
  2636. It is like coming home from the dentist clean except you can have this everyday!

  2642. Since the brush is thin, you can angle it and easily get into tight spaces in your mouth to clean thoroughly.

  2645. There is a built in 2 minute timer to keep you brushing long enough, the battery lasts roughly 2 weeks between charges, and your teeth feel so clean after using.<br /><br

All Reviews

  1. Bought this hoping to have a reliable, well made product. No such luck. And customer &#34;care&#34; is nonexistent. They dont care if you spend over 110 bucks on a toothbrush and it doesn't last. Better products out there for this price. Oh but wait, they did offer me 15% off my next purchase.   2. made a big difference when I had my check up at the denist's office.
  3. This is my 2nd Sonicare and I absolutely love it! I went a little over a month when my last one died and was using a traditional brush because I didn't want to spend the money and my teeth just never felt clean. I used it the day it came in the mail and I felt like I had just left the dentist's office from a cleaning. I will not go without ever again. It is worth the money and I had wonderful dental checkups while using the 1st one but after not using it for a month, got reports of increased tartar buildup and gum sensitivity. This is the best money you can spend, especially with the research now correlating heart and other health issues with oral care.
  4. I absolutely LOVE this product!
  5. Felt weird at first with the intense vibrations if it touched my lip, but I couldn't be happier now with how clean my teeth are. It's like going to the dentist every day.
  6. It's Sonicare, so it's awesome, but I was expecting three speeds. I had ordered three other healthy whites last year for my husband kids and I that come in three speeds: regular, sensitive and white. We had our kids sharing a base with their own heads then decided to just order another brush because of fighting. This brush is blue with the two speeds: regular and white and works fine.
  7. very happy with this product - dentist recommended it highly and if certainly seems to work great. Will continue to use it and replace it when necessary
  8. Love It...The old sonic I used periodically. This one is used twice a day. Would recommend, and yes, my teeth seem to be cleaner...Dentist appointment this Friday....will learn more!.
  9. This was a replacement of my old Sonicare which had seen better days. I expect this one will last even longer.
  10. I had a Sonicare toothbrush for many years and left my charger in a hotel on vacation. I decided I wanted a new one anyway and this one is amazing. I love it!
  11. I've been using a philips sonic toothbrush for years. I usually buy the cheaper $40 models and replace them every two years. I thought I would try this more expensive model to see if there was/is a real difference.....there is. The head is smaller on this unit which allows to get to the back molars much better than the cheaper models. This model seems to have more power and the battery lasts much longer on this one also. Definately worth paying the extra for this one if you are using a sonic toothbrush. Update: I have now had this almost 4 years and this thing is still great. Have just replaced brush ends once a year or so. Battery and power still excellent.
  12. I've had a Sonicare electric toothbrush for many years. I am completely happy with this one too. Keeps my teeth & gums healthy.
  13. haven't used an electric toothbrush in a long time. Now, I am hooked! this product is GREAT! definitely worth the money. narrow shape gets in tricky spots too.
  14. this toothbrush has my teeth feeling so clean and refreshing. I am glad I decided to purchase this product; I will recommend this product to other customers.
  15. This is the second Sonicare I have had. The first gave up the ghost after about eight years and would not charge. I was very pleased with it. I have learned not to form early opinions about electronic products so my opinions are somewhat reserved given I have had this for less than a month. My initial impression was that unlike it's predecessor which was one of the very early Sonicare models, this one seems very flimsy. However, it does everything my original did which was just the basics. If this one is still performing in 3-4 years, I would add the fifth star.
  16. Recommended by two dentists, an orthodontist, and a periodontist over a period of several years. Glad I finally bought it!
  17. My previous electronic toothbrush was a Sonicare E-Series and I never liked how the brush accumulated all this gunk between the head and base. It was impossible to keep clean. My battery on the E-series died out and I decided to replace it with the Sonicare 710. I like the 710 better for several reasons. The toothbrush itself is less bulky, lighter and easier to hold. It also seems to be less noisy. In addition the head is easy to install (it snaps on) and it is very easy to clean between the head and base. The toothbrush comes with a \\"clean and white\\" feature which provides you with an extra 30 seconds to concentrate on the visible part of your front teeth. The one (minor) negative is that the charger does not include space to wrap the extra cord so if you like to keep the charger on your counter you will have a long cord that is always in the way. Fortunately the battery only needs to be charged every few weeks, so I keep my charger stored away until needed. I would recommend this product to anyone looking to purchase an electronic toothbrush.
  18. I was looking for something to help me step up my oral hygiene routine. I first purchased a water pik flosser from Amazon despite the negative reviews. Well they were right...the product probably worked but made too much of a mess. On the advice of my dental hygienist I bought this toothbrush. I immediately noticed a difference in how clean my teeth looked and felt, and within a few days noticed increased whiteness too. I am hooked on this toothbrush! When I was reading the product description, I thought the built in timer seemed unneccessary, but it really is one of it's best features. It made me realize that I probably never brushed for 2 minutes before...it seemed like a long time at first. The 30 second whitening phase at the end is also great...I think it does make a difference.<br /><br />If you are hesitant to buy this, don't be! I won't know until my next check-up, but am willing to bet that this toothbrush will pay for itself in the saving of dental co-pays at that visit. I'm just sorry that I didn't have this 20 years ago.
  19. Best toothbrush I have ever used. Wish that I had purchased this toothbrush years ago. Teeth are so clean, white and sparkly. Better than getting cleaned at the dentist.
  20. (1)It started suddenly in 5 am, and it was really horrible.<br />(2)The toothbrush can't be stopped by pressing the switch button.<br />(3)It stopped until the battery is flat.<br />(4)It is not rechargable any more.
  21. I was doing some research between getting a Sonicare and an Oral-B. I went with the Sonicare simply because it had more positive reviews. I've never tried an Oral-B, but I'm super happy with my purchase.<br /><br />This is my first Sonicare, so the vibration is super ticklish at first. You get used to it within a couple days, though. The reason I got this specific model was mostly for the &#34;quad&#34; feature - where it lets you know when to switch a quadrant of your teeth every 30 seconds. This feature sounds simple, but is actually ridiculously awesome. It makes sure you are actually brushing your entire mouth, rather than just whatever part you keep the toothbrush on.
  22. If you have thin gums, like I do, this toothbrush is terrible for gum recession. I was brushing too aggressively with this product for years, and had to get gum surgery. This toothbrush does not have a sensitive enough setting.<br /><br />The battery life is pretty good, however. This product is not for everyone.
  23. I gave this tooth brush to my girl friend as a gift, she loves it, and I use it when I visit her, it is a great product!
  24. My old Sonicare elite died after about eight years, the battery just wouldn't hold a charge and no longer really cleaned my teeth good. I picked this up as a basic no frills replacement. This thing works great and does an amazing job cleaning. My dentist noticed the next time I went in, she immediately asked &#34;did you get a new toothbrush?&#34; Why yes I did, and I love it! My girlfriend has the diamond, but I didn't really see the need in spending three times as much to do the same job.

  27. I have used a sonicare toothbrush for many years. One aspect I like about this model is that the brush head is easier to clean than was the last which died. I suspect the life expectancy of these power packs could be longer.
  28. Good for clean. However, the white and clean model is not as good as I expected.<br /><br />Used already for around 1 month. Standard brush.   29. Love it! It really makes my teeth clean. I am not builing up tartar behind my bottom teeth which I usually have a problem with.
  30. Previously, we had the Essence, but ended up disliking it for a few reasons. The Essence brush heads had to be screwed on and off and underneath would collect moisture and sometimes noticed a black residue inside. Then we had to soak them in bleach-water to maintain hygiene. It became a nuisance. The other reason I didn't like the Essence, was because the handle is smooth plastic and very slippery when wet. This made it difficult to hold onto and then difficult to dry and then unscrew the brush head. The handle was also very large diameter.<br /><br />Our new Healthy White solved all of those issues. It has a slimmer handle with rubber grips (no slippage). The brush heads pop on and off, so no difficulty with unscrewing or dealing with the hygiene problem. So far, so good!<br /><br />Also, I recommend the ProResults brush heads (didn't care for the HydroClean due to the fact there are fewer bristles). This is an investment in dental and gum health and very much worth the money.<br /><br />One additional remark, we previously also had an Oral B electric (oscillating round head), and that worked well for many years. After menopause, I noticed my gums were a bit more tender due to the abrasiveness, and decided to try the SoniCare. The SoniCare does not irritate my gums at all.
  31. I recievd this toothbrush as a gift, and loved it so much I bought it as a gift for my mom. Now, she is raving about it as much I did. It honestly did whiten my teeth. It's truly a dentist-quality clean with every brushing. Amazon has the best price I've found. Just buy it :)
  32. I just purchased my Sonicare 700 series toothbrush about a week ago at the recommendation of my hygenist. I was diagnosed with preidontal disease, and after the teeth scaling and deep cleaning, I was encouraged to change my toothbrush (I had the Oral B flossing action). One of the main reasons I was told to switch brushes is due to the oxygenation action of the Sonicare, which kills off the anaerobic bacteria that contribute to the peridontal disease. After using the Sonicare for the first time, my Braun toothbrush felt like a toy... My teeth are CLEAN and feel terrific, and I am not noticing the tartar buildup on my lower front teeth as I normally would have had at this time already. I actually look forward to brushing my teeth!!! WELL WORTH THE MONEY you will spend to preserve your dental health.
  33. Second purchase of a Sonicare and my first one died out a little more than a year with the battery. It gave great results, so I figured it was worth another try and this time the focus on the White model. very happy so far and must say a little harder on the teeth, but think may be a little whiter results. Satisfied with it.
  34. My original sonicare is still running strong but apparently the heads for that design are no longer available. Just as well. Prompted me to upgrade to the HealthyWhite design. Much better! Coupons included from the manufacturer made a pack of three extra heads 5.00 cheaper..........a little bonus. More important are my clean white teeth and no cavities in 10 years!! I couldn't imagine going back to a \\"manual\\" brush:-)
  35. I was initially drawn to this product by others' reviews stating that it could make your teeth whiter. I have only been using it a couple of weeks so perphaps I need more time since it hasn't been the case for me. However, in fairness to the product, I only use it at night. During the day, I use an old-fashioned non-electric toothbrush in the interest of saving time. NOTE: if you have sensitive gums, this product is definitely not for you. The toothbrush is a lot stiffer than the older version I used. But I like that the brush itself is smaller and easily reaches way into the back of my mouth so that my molars are now as clean as my front teeth.
  36. This is my third Sonicare toothbrush. I've been using Sonicare toothbrushes for over 15 years. This is my favorite! Much, much better than the other two. I like the slim style, the smaller brush heads, and the whitening effect on my teeth. Put Tom's Wholecare toothpaste on the brush, and my teeth feel like I just had a cleaning at the dentist's office. It doesn't get any better than that!
  37. Trying to get in better dental hygiene habits, and bought one for my husband and myself. We can't stop brushing our teeth! 2...3 times a day! The look of my teeth...but especially my gums...has already improved just after using it for 48 hours. I flossed after using it...and there was nothing to floss! No plaque, nada! Super buy at a super price...I love Amazon! :)
  38. If I can't brush with this toothbrush I don't want to brush at all. This is the best invention since soap.
  39. I love this electronic toothbrush! It works wonders on my teeth and I haven't gotten any cavities since I've been using this toothbrush. I highly recommend purchasing this toothbrush to everyone.
  40. I got a great deal on this from Amazon. Regularly I would expect to pay $20-$30 more than I did for this product. Sonicare came in factory packaging and is in perfect condition. I love this toothbrush because it has an incredible battery life (over ten days for me) and it works wonders. The replacement heads are a little bit expensive (Like $25 for three) and my head did not last for three months, I will have to replace it more often than recommended.
  41. When our old Sonicares stopped working after 4 years, I knew I wanted to get another Sonicare. Even though slightly more expensive, we decided to go with a newer model because the older versions get gunky at the base and under the toothbrush head. Plus, the replacement heads for the newer models are more inexpensive. Therefore, I was left to try to decide between the Flexcare and the HealthyWhite. I went with the 3-mode healthywhite and wished I'd picked the Flexcare. I wish I had known that HealthyWhite just adds 30 seconds to brush time, to let you focus on your front teeth. It doesn't change the way it brushes your teeth for that additional 30 seconds. Pros: 1. Brush head snaps on and is much less gunky than older models 2. Lightweight handle 3. Sensitive mode is nice after dental work 4. Cleans teeth really well--all sonicare models are amazing at cleaning your teeth, even between teeth 5. The three mode HealthyWhite brush comes with a small head for focusing on one tooth at a time like at the dentist's office, and a place on the base to hold it. It looks very compact and neat on the sink. 6. Quad-pacing makes sure you evenly time where you brush your teeth. I include the tops of my teeth with each section, but I've always wished it including time for them in the quad-pacing. But I wouldn't want a Sonicare that didn't offer any pacing. I've gotten used to the luxury. 7. Automatic shut off after 2minutes (and 30 seconds if using HealthyWhite mode). I do wish it were slightly longer. Sometimes I do the 2-min 30second cycle twice, I think 3 minutes would be the perfect amount. Wouldn't buy it if it didn't time you! I like to know I'm brushing long enough. 8. You can opt-out of the gradual increase in power which is nice if you've already been using a sonicare. But I like it for convincing other family members they should be using one! 9. Rechargable and battery lasts for weekend trips without carting the charger with me! Even with me using it more than 2min 30 seconds every time. Cons: 1.\\"Healthywhite\\" option doesn't really do anything but give you 30 seconds longer to brush your teeth 2. You have to press the button 3 times to get to the healthywhite options every time you turn on the toothbrush. It starts in regular clean mode, press again for sensitive and a third time for healthywhite. It would be nice if it could start in the longer mode automatically/remember your preference. If I had it to do over again, I'd buy the Flexcare. I feel like the \\"healthywhite\\" is just a gimmick. The Flexcare is more attractive/modern looking, has all of the \\"pros\\" of the Healthywhite, offers longer timing, and a sanitizer for not much more money.
  42. I have used the product for about two months and have had no problems with it. I am very pleased with its performance.
  43. This is my second Sonicare brush, and both times I had the same bizarre issue. About a year into using it, it started turning on RANDOMLY. Needless to say, this is kind of horrifying--like it has a mind of its own. I was going to wait it out and see if they would repair it under warranty, but the noise was driving me so crazy (and scaring the guinea pigs) that I took apart the brush. This happened with both brushes. It's uncanny. I did really like the brush while it worked. But, in the end, I found my little Preserve toothbrush to be much less fancy and more reliable. And about 1/10th as expensive.
  44. I bought this toothbrush when my almost 10-year-old Sonicare died. I had used whitening kits and they hadn't worked so I thought I'd try this. It took about a month of brushing twice a day with whitening toothpaste, but the results were amazing! My teeth are so white that a co-worker asked me if I had had them professionally whitened! I highly recommend this model of the Sonicare toothbrush.
  45. The main reason I purchased this particular item was because it is dual voltage and I travel a lot. It works great, and very happy with it :)
  46. I bought this R710 Phillips HealthyWhite toothbrush less than 2 years ago. Recently, the metal prong that you place the brush head on became detached from the charger. It was only held in place by the rubber seal. We were able to re-insert the prong, but it would detach again when you removed the brush head from the charger. Now, the rubber seal that holds the metal prong to the charger has now split open and as a result, it is now totally broken. I am so upset that I spent so much money ($112) on this product and then have it last less than 2 years! We were very careful using this product, but nonetheless very disappointed with its durability even with careful use. It does clean your teeth well, but the design is flawed! If you buy this product be sure to register it under the warranty. I regretfully did not, but I don't think it would have mattered.
  47. I've been using this brush for a couple of years now, and it still holds its charge very well - I sometimes go for a couple of weeks without re-charging. Previous electric brushes I've owned all suffered from batteries that would no longer maintain their charge after a while. And oh yes, the dentist noticed right away when I started using it! Just don't whack your teeth with the back of the brush...that thing *really* vibrates. All in all I think this is an excellent electric toothbrush. And here is a tip - don't throw away your old worn out brush heads; use them to clean around the base of faucets etc. - the scale and grime come right off. Don't mix your brushes though :-)
  48. I bought this HealthyWhite brush after my Elite stopped working. This brush is a good upgrade over the Elite as it is thinner, better build quality, and easier to hold. What I like most is the new head that is very easy to clean after every brushing so you are more likely to keep it in better condition. I cannot tell whether there is any cleaning improvement over the Elite but I appreciate the quadrant timer that helps me control my brushing. This loses a star because it did not come with a travelling case.

  55. I never realized you could get that dentist level of clean at home until I tried the Philips Sonicare. This is a terrific tool to have for daily use. It has a 30 second timer for each section of your teeth for a full two minutes of cleaning. This toothbrush leaves your teeth feeling super clean and your breath fresher. I can't see me ever going back to manual brushing!
  56. This is an amazing toothbrush and after using it for a couple months now, I will never go back to standard toothbrushes. My teeth feel cleaner, I don't have to worry about how long I'm brushing b/c the timer is great (has two settings, clean which has 4-30 second intervals and clean & white which has 4-30 second intervals & 2-15 second intervals), and it's easy to use. I really like the travel charger as well b/c it's small, doesn't take up much room, and can be used just about anywhere you travel to if you have an adapter for the different types of endings for different countries. I know the brush heads can get a little expensive, but I've actually found a great deal at Costco for this model when there is a coupon (I think it's 7 brush heads for about $36 with the coupon, which is seasonal but I've seen them go on sale for than once in a year). Costco also has pretty great deals on the toothbrushes themselves when they have coupons, better even than Amazon. People say that the battery doesn't last and maybe I haven't had mine long enough, but I've only charged it maybe 3 times max in the past couple months. I think if you take proper care of your battery and don't leave it on the charger constantly, then your battery will last longer. The toothbrush indicates in various ways (solid light, blinking light) the battery level you currently have. I would definitely recommend reading the instruction booklet before use b/c it has recommendations for care & use.
  57. This toothbrush and most sonicare toothbrushes don't really last longer than three years without the on/off switch starting to malfunction! I have owned three in the last 10 years and no more!!! Three strikes and they are out. Trust me if your toothbrush starts to malfunction after the warranty, they will do nothing to help you. I cannot afford to spend over $100 every 2 or 3 years for a new Sonicare! If I had written a review when I first bought the toothbrush it would have been a glowing review, but now as an experienced user of Sonicare, I say stay away from their products.
  58. I've purchased 2 of these electric toothbrushes and 1 of another model. All three failed after a year of use. When my first one broke because it would no longer brush anymore, I thought it was the battery. I charged it for a day and it still did not function properly. I figured it was a fluke. Then I ordered another one and it happened again. I ordered a different model and the same thing happened. I finally realized that since I travel a lot, I have to remove the brush head from the unit. After repeated removal and installation, I damaged the unit head that attaches to the toothbrush. I figure this is a flaw in the design. The older models where you screw down the brush head was much better and sturdy.<br /><br />On a side note... On one of my units, the brush would be on the charger and mysteriously turn on by itself. At one point I had to put the toothbrush downstairs because the vibration annoyed my wife. I will never spend money on this product again.
  59. The first one of these I purchased was great...very strong and powerful...until it completely died about a month in. I called Sonicare, and they immediately sent me a new one. It started off great like the first one. Then about a year in, I could notice the power diminished greatly. About 1 week after the 2 year warranty expired, this replacement toothbrush completely died. I had felt it slowly losing power until it eventually died. Perhaps I just haven't had good luck, but it looks like others have had this issue as well. I can't vouch for any Oral B rechargeable brushes, but I'm giving up on Sonicare.
  60. My teeth have never felt cleaner!
  61. I bought the SonicareR710 on the advice of my dentist for receding gums. I have yet to be seen by my dentist since using the product but I can definitely say that my teeth feel as clean as when cleaned by a dental hygienist !
  62. This update on the earlier Sonicare toothbrush is a worthy successor. The power handle and its recharging base are more compact, making a convenient fit in medicine cabinets or on counter tops. The HealthyWhite feature is a shift in vibration pattern that is refreshing, if nothing else. The feature results in a slightly longer brushing cycle, which is a good thing. The base wrap around device is not an attractive solution to excessive cord length. The power cord remains thicker than it probably needs to be. It would be nice if the cord was detachable and available in varying lengths. One could then order the desired length. Alternatively, the charging base could be offered with different built in cord lengths. In my location, six or eight inches would be ideal so the long cord is a problematic wad on the counter.
  63. I got this brush as a replacement for my previous Sonicare which was under warranty. The original had the old style heads, so even though Philips sent me a new brush, they still \\"won\\" because I had to buy new brush heads, which aren't cheap. After less than 2 years, this one has now broken, but my warranty is relative to the original purchase, not the age of this brush. They sent me a lame coupon and that's it. I def. have had better dentists visits using Sonicare than I ever did without, but it's pretty annoying to have to shell out $100 every other year for a brush plus the costs of brush heads. Customer support claims the lifetime of their brushes is 3-5 years. As if.
  64. The batteries on my old Sonicare Elite (E-series) died on me, so I decided to get a new one. The R710 has several incremental upgrades which are worth the difference in price.<br /><br />First and foremost, like the FlexCare line, it uses the ProResults head. This alone is worth the price difference. They snap in easily, they cost less, and the handle traps much less gunk than before. Sold. I'm still waiting to see how long they last; my guess is about the same.<br /><br />In addition to the regular cleaning mode, the R710 has a second mode designed to scrub away stains. It's selected by pushing the power button twice. In this mode, the 5th (last) interval of the normal cycle is pulsed in a way that's supposed to break up stains on your visible teeth. Note that after this interval, the brush stops. If you still want to brush your tongue or concentrate on hard-to-reach areas, you'll have to push the power button again.<br /><br />The R710 now also comes with a Li-ion battery, which noticeably decreases the weight and increases the battery life. The charger is about half the size of the Elite's, but it doesn't have anywhere to wrap the cord like the deluxe charger on the Flexcare. It comes with an (optional) snap-on plate that holds two extra heads. The charge indicator is a simple LED. If it's blinking, it's below 50%; if it's solid, then it's above. Maybe not as informative or fun to watch as the Elite or FlexCare, but it does the job.<br /><br />In short, if you want a good basic Sonicare, this is the one to get. It has all the great redesigned features of the FlexCare but less of the (IMO gimmicky) extra routines and modes. If you have sensitive teeth, check out the R732. For an extra $20, it also comes with a few extra accessories like a case and deluxe charger.<br /><br />UPDATE (1/5/2011): My Sonicare failed a few days before the 2-year warranty expired. It powered on, but the action gradually weakened over a week, until the brush head no longer moved at all.<br /><br />Following a short call, Philips promptly sent out a new HX6730 handle along with a return mailer for the defective unit. Great support, as long as you're within the warranty period.
  65. This was my first Sonicare Toothbrush that I bought after reading some of some of the positive reviews here. I was replacing an old Braun that I had for over 10 years. This one seems to have more and faster movements of the brush and it does a better job of cleaning my teeth. You know that feeling after you come out of the dentist's office for a cleaning where your teeth have that polished, smooth feeling when you run your tongue over them? Well, even after the first time using this toothbrush my teeth felt that way. My old toothbrush never did that. After using it for a few weeks my teeth looked whiter to me. Now I never did a real test, like brushing one half with this toothbrush and one half with the old, but when I look at myself in the mirror, I can see a difference.<br /><br />I like the timer thingy on this toothbrush. I thought it would be like a bell or a beep, but it's more like a little pause after each of four 30 second segments. So you do each area of your mouth for 30 seconds and then if you want to do the \\"whitening\\" segment, you push the bottom button and it'll time those segments. This part is a different type of vibration or movement that is supposed to do an even better job of polishing your teeth. I don't know if it's this part or just spending enough time on each section, but it works. My teeth feel cleaner and look whiter.<br /><br />Another thing that I noticed with this toothbrush is that my gums don't bleed when brushing my teeth anymore. I've had that problem for probably the last 30 years, whether I used my old Braun electric toothbrush or whether I brushed my teeth by hand. After the first couple days with this toothbrush it just stopped. I'm not sure if it's because of the texture of the brush or if it's just contributes to the health of my gums, but it's a nice bonus.<br /><br />The toothbrush is very easy to clean and the brushes snap on and off very easily. It's lightweight which makes it easy to use and it's reasonably quiet for a power toothbrush. I'm completely sold on this brand. When I need to replace it at some point, it will be with another Philips Sonicare product. Two thumbs up!quiet for a power toothbrush. I'm completely sold on this brand. When I need to replace it at some point, it will be with another Philips Sonicare product. Two thumbs up!

  68. I have one of this model for myself and have given these as gifts. We're just now discovering that oral hygiene is critically tied to your overall health, particularly cardiovascular health, so as a health professional, I feel really strongly about investing in a good toothbrush. Seriously, just PubMed search this and read the journal articles for yourself. And the studies show that Sonicare hands down is the best toothbrush. The clean you feel after using this brush is unbelievable, IMO. The new head design stays cleaner and is easier to use/manage than the previous screw on design. All the extra fru fru in the expensive version is not worth it (the timer/pacer thing and the UV lamp). Amazon has an awesome price. Phillips customer service is second to none. I had an older model Sonicare that broke after a year unexpectedly (the peroxide from my toothpaste degraded a rubber joint) and Phillips express shipped a brand new brush, no questions asked. Fantastic.
  69. I cannot comment on the life of this brush, as we've only had it for two weeks. The reason I'm reviewing it this early, is that we have all returned from the dentist, and even after having had the brush for such a short time, the reviews were staggering. We picked the brush up the night before our childrens' appointments, and after using the brush just twice the dentist was so impressed with their improved dental habits that it was mind-numbing. Since one of our children is anything but diligent at getting every tooth brushed exactly right... and wasn't even terribly good at remembering to brush every day, this was amazing. I had my own dental appointment this week, after having used the brush for ten days. I'm one of those people blessed with naturally cavity-resistant teeth, but extremely sensitive gums. They have always swelled up & bled if I brushed too hard or flossed at ALL, and they would hurt for days after a simple dental exam. At my own exam, my gums were noticeably healthier, did NOT bleed much at all, and they barely hurt by the time I'd returned home. This is absolutely amazing to me, as I have never had so little discomfort from a dental visit! But what was truly incredible was that they actually said my teeth were noticeably WHITER! Sure I bought the brush to help whiten my teeth as I am a tea-drinker & have permanent staining... but to notice my teeth whitening in less than a month? Wow! Truly, this brush has gone above & beyond my wildest hopes. My \\"problem brusher\\" is now brushing their teeth every morning without my needing to nag them, while my \\"diligent brusher\\" is able to brush their teeth to their hearts-content and feels as if their teeth are really getting clean enough to satisfy them. And I am actually managing to brush away decades of teastains... AND for the first time in my life my gums don't hurt!

  79. My dentist originally told me to steer clear of the rotating brushes to clean your teeth, not much more than taking sandpaper to your teeth. I have since switched dentists, and this gadget had come recommended by many friends, as well as my new dentist. It vibrates the head of the brush at a super high rate of speed. Gone are the days of moving the toothbrush back and forth over your teeth. Simply put on toothpaste, put in mouth, and turn on. Place the head on your teeth and work however you see fit. Every 30 seconds, the tone changes, and you change quadrants in your mouth. This is my one complaint, I'd like to see variable timed (longer) intervals. After two minutes, or 2:30 if you chose the whitening mode, the brush shuts off. Almost four months after having been to the dentist, my teeth still have that super slick clean feeling, I LOVE it!
  80. If you are looking for an electric sonic toothbrush this is the one to get. It has the timer which is very convenient and it has a whitening mode too for your front teeth. I can tell a big difference with the cleaniness of my teeth after using this toothbrush. I recommend 100%!!!

  86. Sure, you would expect a \\"sonic\\" toothbrush to vibrate, but actually it need only twist the brush. I get the impression the stem of the brush wobbles transversely, judging from the effect when it touches a tooth. If you can keep it from touching your teeth, it's just fine.<br /><br />10 months later:<br />Well... It's just fine for ten months. Then it starts itself and runs the battery down. This self-starting problem is pandemic among electric toothbrushes; I've read the same complaint for another brand. Presumably, the toothbrushes are made by one outfit, and branded by resellers.<br /><br />Can you imagine how annoying it is to be awakened at 3 am by \\"Nnxzzgnxzgngz... Nnxzzgnxzgngz-Nnxzzgnxzgngz\\" coming from your bathroom?
  87. I love this product. I have been using a regular toothbrush for the longest until i switched to Sonicare. I love the feeling how my tooth feels after brushing it. battery life is great, cleaning is very easy. Overall a great product.
  88. I have moved up from the Sonicare Elite. They are both quite competent toothbrushes and I'd recommend either. Also, the brush head is less expensive to manufacture than the Elite head and should be less expensive than it is. It is still less expensive than the Elite, which contains 2 rare earth magnets in each head. The Healthy White head does not. I really think that Philips should pass along this savings. I love both items, but I currently use the Healthy White.

  93. I floss my teeth maybe 3 times year (if that) and 90% of the time I only brush once a day - in the past, my bad habits have resulted in a cavity or two every time I visited the dentist. I have not had a cavity since making the switch. My teeth are also whiter and my mouth feels clean. As far as this Sonicare vs the other models by Sonicare. This version is just as effective and costs significantly less.
  94. I was not sure how I would adjust to an automatic toothbrush, but after a week or so I successfully made the transition and would not go back. This is a basic brush, but works very well. I have noticed some whitening effects so far, but mostly I like the nice clean feeling I get every time without gum or tooth sensitivity. The proof will be in the pudding (when I return to the dentist) but for now I am completely satisfied. I'm hoping I don't see any issues that others describe, but if so I will update the review.
  95. I have been using the brushes that spin or vibrate for years and thought I was brushing good. I've always had trouble with keeping my gums healthy and having them bleed a little when brushing no matter what I did or how often I did it. It was time to get a new toothbrush recently and I decided to take the plunge and get a high-end, more expensive toothbrush. This is something I never thought I would do because I never really thought there would be that much value in it. Boy was I wrong. This is the most amazing toothbrush I have ever used. My teeth feel so clean it's almost scary. In one week I have noticed at least a shade or 2 gain in whiteness, and my gums no longer bleed. I can't say enough about just how amazed I am by that. The brush heads on my old toothbrush would wear out within 4-6 weeks. The Phillips heads are supposed to be good for at least 3 months before needing to be replaced, so over the life of the toothbrush I think it's actually going to cost me a considerable amount less. If any of you are not sure whether to take a chance and spend so much on a toothbrush, DO IT! Your dental health is worth it and you won't be disappointed.<br /><br />UPDATE: After 1 year my SoniCare is still in perfect shape, still holds a charge for about 2 weeks before letting me know it's time to recharge, and my teeth are whiter and my gums are stronger than at any other time in my life. I still HIGHLY recommend this toothbrush. I'll be getting the kids version for my daughters now that they are getting old enough to make use of it.
  96. I've been using the Oral B electric for as long as I can remember and when my latest one died of old age I wanted to investigate the market. I ended up buying this model [[ASIN:B0019ZEVZU Philips Sonicare HealthyWhite Power Toothbrush]]. The first time I used it I knew the Sonicare was a great improvement - it simply is a better instrument. I've been using it about a month now and coincidentally I had a regular dental appt a few days ago. The hygienist knew something was up, she remembers me because I have periodontal disease and she has to use her \\"special instruments\\". I told her as much as the Oral B is better than manual brushing - the Sonicare is that much better over the Oral B. She and the dentist are Oral B users but as the hygienist said \\"the proof is in the results\\". I don't think Sonicare is packaging this model anymore so I don't know how many readers this review will reach, but if your at all hesitant - spend the extra money and get the best - its worth it. A final caveat - I cannot speak to the durability yet.
  97. Thinner than the old sonicares. If you turn it off to spit, it doesn't turn back on to the time you left it. Small details. I have crowns and bridges and implants and this toothbrush will help extend their life. Recommended for sure.
  98. Does the job but I like the older model better (non-curved brush). This model does not massage and clean the gum line as well.
  99. excellent product. Long lasting battery between charges. makes teeth feel polished. Very happy with purchase.
  100. This tooth brush is amazing. I have never enjoyed brushing my teeth this much. I just bought it, and I have not seen all of it's effects yet, but I can say in the few times I have used it, I have never felt my teeth this clean ever. In fact, they feel that way almost all day because it has such a deep clean. This may be bizarre, but in all my brushing before this, when I brushed and then would spit out the toothpaste, it would normally still be around the same color of the toothpaste. The Sonic Care does such a great job getting the grime off your teeth that when you are finished and you spit out the toothpaste you are truly spitting out all the stuff that is on your teeth. Just shows how much I thought I was getting my teeth clean with an ordinary toothbrush to now. I highly recommend this!!!
  101. Using this brush makes my teeth feel much cleaner. Whether or not they are actually any cleaner I could not say, but they definitely FEEL cleaner. The brush has a built in timer so that you can just turn it on and it will remain powered up for a certain amount of time and then you know you are finished brushing unless you just want a marathon cleaning. The interchangeable heads make it a very nice addition for both me and my wife as we only had to purchase one toothbrush and just use two different heads.
  102. My prosthodontist suggested I buy one, and one that took the Diamond Brush heads (Healthy White, Flexcare or Diamond).. Immediately, the teeth feel cleaner, even though I had brushed for a longer time with a regular toothbrush... I charged it fully before use and have had 30 brushings (15 days) without a recharge.. and my prosthodontist saw the results after only three weeks of use and was so impressed, called in the hygenist to see the results..<br /><br />I was happy with the price here of $74.. Costco had pair (two handles) for $119, but I don't need two handles.. Did pick up a 6-pack of Diamond brush heads at Costco for $39..
  103. I am not new to electric toothbrushes, but I am definitely new to the high end spectrum. My entire family uses the Essence, but when the HealthyWhite Sonicare went on sale on Amazon, I took the plunge. I was not disappointed. Initially, the new style of brushing takes some getting used to. It is pretty powerful and can turn some people off if they are not used to electric toothbrushes. It also cleans totally differently than the cheaper drugstore electric toothbrushes. I will say that the Quadpacer technology is awesome. It ensures that I get my teeth evenly clean and spend enough time doing the job. I have had it for about two weeks now and my teeth are noticeably whiter after using the Clean and White setting. I would recommend this toothbrush to anyone over the Essence if you want white teeth, and the bonus is that the brush heads are cheaper.
  104. I bought this brush for my deployment to Iraq in 2011 and it has been the perfect deployment toothbrush. I needed a brush with a dual voltage charger (110,220) and one that would be superior to other battery operated brushes . The brush has fantastic power, it cleans easily, and the head portion is removable if I have to store it in a small toiletry bag. However, the most amazing attribute has been the battery life. I charged the brush on January 14th, and then didn't have to charge it again until June 16th, over 5 months later. I am certain that is not normal for any battery powered brush, and after a while it became an interesting game to see how long it was going to last. I use the brush daily, sometimes twice a day, and it still had strong battery power right up until the day I finally had to recharge it. It was if Sonicare inadvertently created a perpetual energy battery. I am now on day 46 of use again without having to recharge. Buy this brush because it is a great toothbrush, enjoy it for how long the battery seems to last.
  105. My old (could it be 10 years old? -- maybe) Sonicare was working great but I could no longer find brush heads for it. So grudgingly I bought a new model. I'm very happy I did.<br /><br />Compared to the older model, this is smaller, lighter, and easier to handle. Not that the old one was cumbersome -- this model is just a little more elegantly designed. The shape of the brush head is more slender and easier to use. My teeth and gums really do seem cleaner after I use it.<br /><br />It has some bells and whistles I don't really care about -- it needs some combination of button pushes to activate and turn off. I haven't bothered to figure them out -- I usually follow the beeps and finish brushing when it does, and if I'm in a hurry I brush a bit and then push that power button repeatedly until it goes off. Maybe some cold day this winter I'll take the time to figure it out.<br /><br />Bottom line -- I really like it.

  110. My dentist suggested I get a Sonicare toothbrush as it would help my gums as well as my teeth. I can't believe the difference this toothbrush makes. My whole mouth feels clean after every brushing in a way I've never felt before. The best news is that my dentist says he sees a difference.
  111. Does what it should. Can get a good number of brushes out of a single charge. Has some lame &#34;whitening mode&#34;. I have not found any utility for this. I also don't like the timer, which cannot be turned off.
  112. It's great in typical sonicare fashion. I don't use the whitening function as often as I would like just because there is one button that is shared for \\"clean\\" and \\"clean and white\\". So you have to cycle through to the second feature to use the whitening feature. Also, because there's one button that's used to cycle there isn't a pause function. If you remember older models you could put it into pause by pressing the button and then resume by pressing again. Hard to imagine that they would skimp on that one button considering what they're charging for these things.
  113. A replacement for one I have had for years. It is responsible for my good dental visits and highly recommended by my dentist.
  114. I love this product. I have had no problems with it at all.. just shop around for a great price..
  115. I had one of those old giant Sonicares for many years. Was getting cracked from the heat, the brushes were beyond gone. The HealthyWhite model seemed like it had what I needed in features, sort of the happy medium, so that is what I got. Slim and stylish in retro-modern light green and off-white, perching on a much nicer recharging stand that isn't disgusting and heat-stained like my old one. A more hygienic design all around and it has a thinner and more comfortable brush assembly. Per the directions, I voided the break-in mode that is for those new to electric brushes and can find the vibrating action uncomfortable for awhile. I use the whitening cycle which gives you four thirty-second segments, one for upper outer teeth, one for upper inner and so on. Each segment's time is signaled my a very brief motor pause. Then, for the whitening mode it switches to a more vigorous action. When that cycle is up, the thing turns off. That is a lot of brushing, frankly more than ideal for me. I don't really enjoy the whole oral care thing at all, I hate to floss for example, but this makes it the most tolerable for me and now I do it all just like you are supposed to. Clearly a vastly better experience than old generation electric brushes and would think hugely more effective than most people are going to get from a regular brush. Uninsured dental care is really expensive. I obviously don't have the tooth science background to discuss the merits of every brand out there, I imagine they end up being somewhat similar in terms of cleaning and plaque removal, but this model is relatively affordable, does seem to be very effective, is hygienic and easy to clean. The brushes are readily available. It looks good. Just fine in my opinion. Aside from some magic new technology that may be out there, I doubt that it can be much better. Whitening is a hope. I want that diamond glint like in the movies (on demand of course), but I am pretty sure there is a limit to what one can expect. Some people simply have those ultra-white teeth and others never will, but this and some sort of whitening strips or treatment is probably going to give you the best possible results.
  116. Havent been to a dentist to know if it prevents plaque buildup but after brushing the mouth does feel fresh. Its head is small enough to reach corners of the mouth and as of now (after 3 months) it seems to be working wonderfully!
  117. Please be aware that with normal usage this product has a life expectancy of less than to just over one month. However, with this Programmed-toothbrush, I have to get the 2min 30secs job done and it's not boring at all.   121. I purchased this as a replacement for my old Sonicare, which finally packed it in after close to a decade. After using a much older model for so long, I'm pleased to see the improvements, such as making it REALLY easy to keep clean. The old ones had several parts that needed to be taken apart and cleaned in order to prevent mildew because dark, moist spaces and things that go in my mouth are not a pleasant combination. The new models are more streamlined and only the head is removed for cleaning and replacement. I can't compare it to other electric toothbrushes because I've only ever used the Sonicare brand, but I'm so happy with how my clean my teeth feel that I'm not really inclined to shop around.

  132. Today's Sonicare Toothbrushes break quickly, as they are not well sealed. This is my 3rd Sonicare toothbrush over (+10 years), but the quality of manufacture and lifetime of the toothbrushes has precipitously dropped. This one didn't even last to it's 3rd birthday! You think for the amount they charge and the cost of the replacement heads, they could make something that would last longer. I also dislike how sonicare has made so many models of what is essentially the identical toothbrush, but with minor setting differences. It used to be all the sonicare toothbrushes have a normal and soft mode, but now you have to pay for the highest level model for this feature, though it really does not cost anything additional for this feature. The Philips customer service call center is not responsive to the problem and insisted the toothbrush failed because it's \\"not designed to be waterproof,\\" which is ridiculous. They suggested it failed because of overcharging, but this is patently not the case, because when I opened the toothbrush head there was a ton of moisture inside. Sorry to get geeky here (I'm an engineer), but the design IMO poor, as there's is no water adsorbing material to wick moisture that penetrates the 3 different o-ring seals (at the base, toothbrush top, and button). See the pictures of the inside. I can fix the toothbrush by pushing my pocketknife between the battery and the terminal (terminal corroded. Anyway, doubt this will fix anything since the circuit has already started corroding in various spots, as has the motor. This is typical of how they fail, consider yourself warned!!!! (see pictures of inside)
  133. This was just what the Dentist wanted us to get and we followed his directions. This has turned out to be a helpful addition to our cleaning regimine.
  134. I bought this to replace an older E-series model (don't remember the exact name; I had used it for about 10 years, but it would be comparable to today's \\"Essence\\" model.) This provides the same quality cleaning, with the advantage of not having a screw-on head that collects gunk underneath. (It was always a little frightening to see what was living inside my toothbrush, and it's not like I never cleaned in there. It's just a bad design.)<br /><br />The only thing I don't like about the HealthyWhite compared to the other is the handle is slimmer, so the vibration is stronger against my hand. This was very annoying at first, but I've gotten used to it and it no longer bothers me.<br /><br />I haven't used the \\"clean and white\\" setting as it doesn't do anything but add a little time to the brushing cycle. So I consider that pretty worthless as a feature. Any brush would give you extra cleaning time by just pressing the start button again.<br /><br />My husband has been using the HealthyWhite for about 3 years now, and I tried his before getting my own. The charge stand has 2 pegs for extra heads, so it is possible to share the handle. I would have preferred to do that, but swapping out the heads became too irritating. The head pops on easily, but getting it off is a bit of a struggle. I usually had to wrap a towel around the head and wiggle and yank until it came free. So I took off a star for that. A small release button for the head would have made this a perfect handle, as is it ranks \\"only\\" 4 stars.<br /><br />A note about charging the Sonicares: I saw in other reviews that several people have had problems with their handles dying prematurely. I don't know if this makes a difference, but we have always kept ours on the charge stands when not in use and have never had a problem with a handle dying, even after a decade or more of use. As a bonus, the HealthyWhite charge stand is very small and keeps the handle upright, so it uses a minimum of counter space.
  135. The first day I used this electronic toothbrush, I felt a cleanliness that wasn't comparable to a regular toothbrush. Great for a through cleaning. And from the 3 modes to choose from they are sufficient enough. I can tell this product will be with me for a quite awhile.

Just follow the included instructions and you will not be disappointed.   141. I had been so frustrated with my Sonicare Essence toothbrush that I was actually excited when the unit finally stopped taking a charge. I did a lot of research on Amazon and other websites and it came down making a decision between Oral-B and Sonicare. I actually bought an Oral-B Professional Care toothbrush at Costco just to try out the features and compare it to the sonic technology. I didn't like the small circular brush heads and I felt that the spinning of the bristles didn't do nearly as good a job as the vibrating Sonicare technology. I promptly returned this item and set out to by a new Sonicare product.<br /><br />My biggest complaint with the E-series was the incredibly poor design of the toothbrush heads that had to screw into the base unit. Smelly funky slimy stuff would start to grow inside the unit and all around where you would screw the items together - just a terrible design. I was happy to see that both the Healthy White and Flexcare products no longer had this stupid screw-on design. After lots of research I couldn't find any key differences between the Healthy White and Flexcare sonic technologies so I went with the cheaper of the two.<br /><br />After a week of use I have no complaints with the toothbrush at all. If you're used to Sonicare brushes then you will not be disappointed with this toothbrush. Of the two modes I use the more powerful one, but my wife prefers the softer mode. You can use a variety of toothbrush heads and none of them look to have that slimy gunk buildup problem.
  142. Love how well it cleans my teeth, but hate how hard they made it to replace the battery. I probably shouldn't have put it on the charger all the time, because my sonicare lost its &#34;voom&#34; after about 10 months -- rendering it unusable. Good as new after replacing the battery, though!<br /><br />The battery's a Sony US14500VR2, which I replaced with a 14500 Sanyo 3.7V unprotected Li-ion rechargeable battery (840mAh, from orbtronic.com). I used only a butter knife and a pointy knife. I opened the battery compartment with the butter knife by rotating about 30 degrees counter-clockwise until it popped slightly, pushed down on the tip to get the assembly out. I then used the pointy knife to separate the battery terminals from the tabs. The tabs are spot welded to the battery, but 5 minutes of prying and wiggling later, you can lift out the old battery and plop in the new one. Make sure to leave the tabs soldered to the circuit board, of course.
  143. This product was recommended by my dentist. On recommendation from a seminar on dental health, I bought my friend one for a present and she had no complaints. When my old brand died, I bought this product. Good products but it takes some getting used to when you switch from brands. The sonic care vibrates significantly.

  148. I'm a college student and when the semesters would get hectic I started drinking coffee like crazy! So as you can imagine, my teeth would gradually get more and more yellow. And I'm great about dental hygiene so this was driving me insane! No matter how much I brushed with my manual toothbrush, the yellow remained.   149. Very effective at cleaning your teeth.   150. This is the second Sonicare I purchased, the first one lasted about 18 months before battery died. Had some erroding gums due to brushing too hard and some plaque build up on the far back mollars that was always being scrapped every 6 months. after 6 months of use, my gums have recovered and no more plaque build up. Replacement heads are a little high, but in the end it probably cost less than $10/month. I think it's worth it.<br />Three issues that aren't bad, but be aware of : when you hit your teeth with the brush head the vibration will freak you out the first several time; you have to keep your mouth completely shut around the brush head or you will be cleaning your mirror every day; you need to cleaning between the head and the battery handle of you will get toothpaste build up.

  153. Our dentist has been recommending this brand for a few years. My wife bought one in July and gave me the same one for Christmas because she liked it so much. Teeth feel clean. The 30-second timer helps to make sure all teeth get equal time. I usually use the second 2 minute period to give an even better cleaning. Also the smaller base on the brush head helps with keeping it clean. We took a 17-day road trip in the U.S. and found it to keep its charge if it was plugged in only overnight.
  154. worked great for about 3 months and then died. It just hummed for a while when you turned it on. My first Sonicare lasted for 10 years. I figured that I got a dud and ordered the newer version of this. It has been working great for year. Three stars - but I think it was just a lemon. I like Sonicare.
  155. My husband & I have been using the HealthyWhite for a little over a week now and we both agree that it gives our teeth the best brushing we've ever had at home. Our new dentist and the dental hygienist recommended Sonicare to us both as we both have some gum recession and sensitivity. Rather than just go right out and purchase the first Sonicare we saw on the shelf, we decided to look at the available options. The other big player in the power toothbrush game is Oral B. There are several others as well, but reviews were difficult to find so the choice eventually came down to Sonicare or Oral B. Also considering that power toothbrushes run on the pricey side (for us anyway), I insisted on doing research. My research included: Visiting both the Sonicare and Oral B websites and reading about all the different models; reading online reviews, including Amazon reviews, for each of the different models; and a lengthy discussion with our dental hygienist. The companies' websites were useful for general information. For me, though, the Amazon and other online reviews, were much more helpful in pointing out problems/successes with both Sonicare and Oral B power toothbrushes. I actually looked at reviews for each Sonicare and Oral B models. After reading the reviews for the lower priced (and apparently older? Sonicare models), like the Essence, I determined that I did NOT want to purchase any of those models. The primary reason: The design of these brushes apparently allows water/toothpaste to seep into part of the brush handle in such a way that mold forms. With the HealthyWhite and the Flexcare, Sonicare solved this problem, but I was very skeptical about spending nearly $100 (or more!) for a toothbrush. The Oral B apparently does not suffer from the design flaw of the lower priced Sonicare models and I was actually all set to go ahead with one of the lower priced Oral B models, until I spoke with the dental hygienist. Following that conversation, I concluded that even if I purchased an Oral B for my own dental needs, we would still need to purchase a Sonicare for my husband, whose needs exceed mine a bit. For us then it made sense to buy one brush handle and just purchase another brush head. Although I had read about the difference between sonic dental technology (which Sonicare uses) and oscillating/rotating technology (that Oral B uses), it didn't really make sense to me until my conversation with the hygienist. The way it was basically explained to me as follows (Sorry if this is a bit graphic): Sonic technology mixes the toothpaste with your own saliva. The \\"sonic\\" part of the technology not only reaches the surface of the teeth but into spaces that no traditional brushing mechanism can reach, even getting in and around the gums. The Oral B apparently uses the more \\"traditional\\" brushing technology and only cleans the area that the bristles of the brush themselves can reach. This changed my mind, especially in light of my husband's dental needs. At that point, it made more sense to buy one of the newer Sonicare models. When I first used the Sonicare I expected it to be very loud based on reviews I had read. In my opinion it is quieter than my hairdryer, the noise of which does not bother me. It did take both of us a few days to get used to the feeling of the brush on our teeth. The Quadpacer technology is helpful, as is the timing mechanism that all Sonicare brushes have, but not really essential in my case: I prefer the longer \\"Clean and white\\" cycle and sometimes find that that is not long enough for me. Some criticize the auto shutoff, but the easy solution to that is just to turn the brush back on. I can always turn it off if I don't want to go through another 2 minutes. I was a little surprised that the charger is so light and that the brush handle does not fit securely onto the charger: It just rests on the charger and could easily be knocked off. The charger does have room to hold 2 other brushheads. I have not had any problems with the brushhead popping off the handle when I am brushing my teeth. I do have to be careful about keeping my mouth closed when I am brushing as well as remembering to not start the brush until it's in my mouth. Overall, though we are very happy with our Sonicare and we really hope it results in better dental appointments. If it does, then it is well worth it despite the higher price tag. My issue with the auto shutoff and the charger do not outweigh the benefits of this brush. I would recommend this toothbrush, but before doing so I would first recommend talking to your dentist/hygienist and doing your own research. Everyone's dental needs are unique and this brush (or any Sonicare) may not be the right fit for all. Also, for those of you who do buy a Sonicare, if you register the brush with Sonicare (either online or with the card that comes in the package),the company will send coupons for additional products. I have not yet registered our brush so I don't know how well this works or what kind of coupons Sonicare sends.
  156. The Sonicare Advance I had for too many years to remember when I first got it, was a rock- 100% dependable for a long time and very solid. This HealthyWhite feels flimsy. It works fine. But given the price, and the price of replacement brushes, I have to wonder, will it last ten years? I doubt it. It's got that 'one drop on a tile floor and throw it away' feel. Again, I'm comparing it to the Advance, which was really built by another company altogether. I'm not telling you anything after a month, only time will tell. But go to a Target and see if you like the feel before you order it on-line. Also, the base in chintzy- cheap. Horrible? No. But it could have been much better. Last point, I'd read some people (on Amaxon) saying their brush heads flew off the handle, so it stuck in my head. From my experience, this is not a concern- the way the brushes click onto the handle is secure and well designed and MUCH more convenient than the Advance model I started out by complementing.
  157. I only purchased this newer model because my old Sonicare Elite's battery was dying. Initially I bought the new version of the Elite and was sorely disappointed as it was heavier (!) than my old toothbrush. For reference, Elite uses the cup-shaped screw-on head that trapped goop and mildew. I returned that toothbrush (cheaper intro model) and \\"upgraded\\" to this HealthyWhite style toothbrush and am so glad I did. The newer models that use the ProResults toothbrush head - the redesigned, smaller and more hygienic (no mildew nor slime)- are pretty much the same - just a difference in how many cycles are available. This newer design not only was lighter but also more effective. Those stats claiming x% more effective cleaning for this model in the Sonicare comparison table were hard to believe but I was convinced one night after a few glasses of red wine stained my front teeth. I could not get the dark stains off with the old Sonicare Elite. Normally I'd use Crest Whitestrips to bleach the stain out. This time I tried using my new HealthyWhite brush and it brushed the stain off in the first 30 seconds! Wow, that alone saves me from having to bleach whiten my teeth, never mind having a cleaner set of teeth. If you have an older Sonicare model it is very worthwhile to spend the $$ and upgrade. The toothbrush head redesign is a godsend - no more slimy mildewy mess. And the cleaning effectiveness is amazing!
  158. Philips has a policy of using battery and charging base materials that stop working soon after the warranty period to maintain you as a repeat customer. I am switching over to water pik and from what I can tell they use better quality materials to begin with and prices are similar. Buy Philips Sonicare at your own risk.

  163. So far I love this toothbrush. Its been about a month, no probs. I read many reviews and I am following some advice such as only charging when needed (I havent had to charge since the first day I got it) and also not getting toothpaste into the crack where the brush attaches. Only a small amt of toothpaste is needed. When I brush I do not allow toothpaste and saliva to drip down the brush (thats so gross). I take the brush off and store them apart. I havent had any paste or water get into that area at all.

  169. update: like this enough that I got another one for the office -------------------------------- I had used the E-series type of brush for about 15 years and when the battery on the last one died ordered one of these 1. it does seem to clean better, the teeth feel noticeably smoother than with the E-series type design 2. it is much easier to clean- the snap on brush is a much better design than the screw on type design of the E-series 3. the smaller brush gets into the nooks and crannies better- I have big teeth that are a bit out of alignment 4. the \\"healthywhite\\" function is nice but hitting the start button twice does not always engage it overall this is a big step up from the E-series type design and costs about the same will have to wait and see how long the battery lasts and have not yet checked how many uses it gives on a full charge (the charger is pretty small and can be taken on trips)
  170. This is my very first electric toothbrush and I'm totally in love with it! I really leaves your teeth clean, it's easy to use and to keep clean. I also love the timer features and the fact that it isn't loud at all (don't need to worry about waking my husband up early in the morning). Highly recommend this little one! Very happy with my purchase.
  171. After many, many years of using an older model sonicare toothbrush, it was time to replace it as the batteries no longer held a charge very well. Obviously the older model was very durable. The only negative aspect of the older sonicare was that the detachable brush head accumulated a nasty layer of toothpaste and gunk between the body and brush head. The new brush head solves that problem. I was a little worried when considering the new model as some of the reviewers complained about the brush head coming off while they were using the toothbrush. I wanted to have some experience with the new sonicare before writing the review so that I could address this issue. I have used the new sonicare for more than 6 months. I have had no problems with the brush head coming off during use. In my opinion, the new brush head attachment design is a great improvement. I have previously used electric toothbrushes from other makers as well as the older sonicare. The sonicare R710 is the best electric toothbrush I have used.

  187. I bought my first Sonicare toothbrush back in 2002, an original E-series, and I used it until it wouldn't recharge any more, which was about Christmas 2008. After using a manual toothbrush a few weeks, I decided I simply had to get another Sonicare. I upgraded to the R710, and I couldn't be happier. The lithium batteries make it smaller, lighter, easier to handle, and just more... toothbrush-like. The E-series always was a handful. Plus, Sonicare has apparently improved their ultrasonic technology over the last 6 years... the R710 is significantly more powerful than my old one was. The only downside I've found is that, since the R710 has 2 cleaning modes (whereas my old model had only one), turning the unit off in mid-cycle requires pressing the button twice instead of just once. The first press switches modes, and the second press finally turns it off.
  188. Fire and forget. This is what you want.<br />I've had one for a few months now and find it works well. It's reliable, has a good feel, keeps the brush recharged, and lasts. It really has just one mode worth futzing with and no fancy readout. For years my wife and I had used disposable electric toothbrushes. This feels about the same except the brushes seem to last longer and as it's rechargeable, of course, you don't throw it away. It's just one more aspect of life simplified. Pair this with a waterpik and your dental hygienist will look forward to your visits.

  195. Love their products, just bought another one. Not to get all PC on everyone, but is Philips really convinced that calling a product 'White Power' will help their North American marketing? Given that Philips ain't from around here, it's hard to see how people who aren't members of the Church of the Perpetually Offended would rate it much higher than a middling hoot. But it is a large Church, after all, and its worshippers are doubtless members of the toothbrush-purchasing public. I certainly hope Philips wasn't striving for irony: imagine an American product marketed in the UK under the trademark \\"Skinhead\\". Or maybe \\"Lebensraum\\" for Eastern Europe and an economical \\"Generalissimo\\" for the South? Come to think of it, how about a brand name that would offend everyone: \\"EU\\"?

  200. I have been using a Sonicare Elite for several years. When the battery finally died, I purchased the HealthyWhite toothbrush. The toothbrush feels good in my hand and the new ProResults brush feels like it covers more tooth surface and thus cleans better. The lithium-ion battery is a great improvement and I have used it for two weeks without having to recharge it. This performance will come in handy on trips and vacations. The clean and white feature gives an extra 30 seconds of run time so you can concentrate on the teeth in the front of your mouth for that extra bit of cleaning. The one thing that irks me is the charging base. It is very light and can move on your counter top if the cord is moved in any way. A bit more weight in this area would be beneficial. Overall, I have found this brush to be worth the money and it seems to be a well designed and made toothbrush. My Elite was made in the U.S. but the HealthyWhite is made in China. I hope over time it proves to be as durable and reliable as my Elite was.

  209. My husband and I both have this toothbrush. It's reasonably priced and does a great job. There's two problems with it though.. 1) Make sure you shake off the water because it falls to the bottom and just sits there, which can create mold. 2) Take of the brush attachment and clean that area often. If you see any kind of growth (yes, gross) on the rubbery portion there, DO NOT try and take it off. Breaking the seal will cause it to stop working because eventually water will get in there. This happened on both our units and had to purchase new ones. The growth happens quicker that you think.

  219. I am in love with this product. I have seen a difference in how white my teeth are after 2 weeks. It gives you a cleaner brush than any other toothbrush on the market.   220. My 15 year old Sonicare finally gave up working and I had to buy a replacement. I ended up buying this one and am happy with it. So what's the problem? I found it almost impossible to wade through Sonicare's marketing materials to discover which brush was best for me. 15 years ago Sonicare had one product. Turn it on, let it vibrate, brush your teeth. These days, the product is essentially the same, the only difference is now you can buy a unit that vibrates a little, a little more, a little more again, etc. You get the drift. But they don't market them like I just described. They market them using goofy labels like \\"Diamond Clean\\". Do you have any idea whether you want \\"Diamond Clean\\", \\"Ultimate Clean\\" or \\"Advanced Clean\\"? I don't either. And they have a Sonicare for \\"Gum Care\\" and a different one for \\"Whiter Teeth\\". I guess if you want both gum care and white teeth you either have to pick one over the other or buy two? Its silly marketing. This particular unit is the cheapest one with the new syle thin brush heads. It has two vibration levels. If it was 10 bucks cheaper and had only one vibration level I'd like it even better.
  221. i purchased this at walgreens for fifty more dollars than what it sells for here, so if you can get it for under a hundred, it's a steal.<br /><br />then, it's an investment because it's going to pay for itself with the money you save by not having to have to have your teeth cleaned and by not having to go to the dentist to have cavities filled.<br /><br />and i can compare it with the oral b electronic toothbrush it's in a league of it's own. the comparison is like a mercedes compared to a ford pinto. it costs more, but it's an entirely different product and performs at an entirely different level. read the other reviews.<br /><br />on a full recharge, the charge lasts for about twenty five brushes or more. i haven't counted exactly. it goes for about two weeks. don't leave your toothbrush on the charger or you'll ruin the battery.<br /><br />it's a quality product that is worth every cent you pay for it. this item along with other dental health products: waterpik, listerine, hydrogen peroxide, baking soda, toothpaste, and you'll never have a problem with bad breath or with your teeth. except for one thing; if your teeth are compromised already, this brush may be hard on them. my dentist recommended i have a crown on a tooth, and pointed out how i've neglected my teeth, then after purchasing the soniccare it shook the filling out the compromised tooth. i suspect some of the bad reviews may point to this problem, but i can testify with certainty that the problem was on my end. i didn't take care of my teeth because i should have had one of these years ago. but better late than never. i'm glad i own one of these.
  222. We have used Sonicare toothbrushes for years and this one seems as good, or better, than the others. However, I feel I made two mistakes: 1) This model does not come with a carry case 2) I purchased at Target, could have saved $30 through Amazon. Yea, could return it, but...

My dentist said using an electric toothbrush cleans your teeth about 70% better than a manual one so I figured it was definitely worth a try. My teeth do feel cleaner and I like the timer on it that helps you keep track on how long you've been brusing and beeps when it's time to move the brush to another area of your mouth. As far as noticing whiter teeth - not really sure I've seen much on that but that could just take a little more time as it's only been a few weeks now. Overall I do like the product and have no regrets on purchasing it. And as usual Amazon not only offered the best price but it was delivered quickly as well.
  226. This is my favorite toothbrush for sure.... works just as described and I love all of the features. Also, the charge lasts over 3 weeks.... I haven't let it die all the way yet, but I've only been charging it every three weeks.
