  232. I decided that I needed a litte bit more hate in my life, and the Sonicare white power toothbrush fit the bill. Now I can curb stomp with my buddies with sparkling white teeth. Thanks philips!
  233. I have used Sonicare toothbrushes since they came out. My first one, the Advance lasted 12-13 years! My second, E-series, lasted less than two before it started doing the random turn-on thing and then just died altogether. Because they come so highly recommended by my dentist, and because I do feel like my teeth are really, really clean after I use them, I decided to try out this new healthywhite version.<br />I like the new design of the head; I used to open up my brush every week and spray the inside with anti-mildew spray to prevent mildew and general grossness from building up in there. This new design doesn't allow for that to happen, so that is nice. I like how it cleans my teeth. I like the smaller size of the entire base and that the base is easier to clean than the larger previous models.<br />However, the brush heads do NOT stay on. Luckily, I haven't had one hit me in the face like the other reviewers, but they fly off and land in the sink or floor, or simply just come apart in my mouth. Annoying. The brush came with some plastic ring thing, I have no idea what it was supposed to do, it neither helped seal the brush head on the base nor did it prevent the gap between the two, and one of the times the brush head flew off when I was brushing, the ring went down the drain. I've tried the sonicare brand brush head and the target brand brush head, they both are very loose, with the target one being worse. I can't keep the thing on. I am not sure how well it is able to clean loose or when i have to hold it against the brush, while brushing my teeth.<br />I have had the thing for less than six months and it is practically useless. I do not have the box or receipt any more so I guess I am stuck with it. If Sonicare is going to make these brushes significantly less quality than their predecessors, why do they still cost $80-$100+?<br /><br />***Update***<br />Found the box, called the number. They agreed to send me new brush heads. One week passed, no brush heads showed up but then my toothbrush started turning on randomly (and scaring the heck out of me!!) But this was the same thing my old one started doing right before it died. So I called again, and they sent me another tooth brush. This one seems to be an updated version of the same model (whitening one). The brush head firmly connects to the base and, so far, all is well.hbrush started turning on randomly (and scaring the heck out of me!!) But this was the same thing my old one started doing right before it died. So I called again, and they sent me another tooth brush. This one seems to be an updated version of the same model (whitening one). The brush head firmly connects to the base and, so far, all is well.
  234. I love this toothbrush. It's worth the money if you can get it on sale. I find that the whitening feature isn't really producing any major results for me, but I still love the clean. Since I have braces right now, it really helps make sure no little food pieces get stuck in my teeth or between the wires. My favorite features of this product are: -The Timer: it tells you when to switch areas of your mouth and when to stop -The Internal Battery, so you don't have to mess with AAs -The Sonic movement: It cleans much better and moves in a quicker, more different way than cheap electric toothbrushes -From what I can see, it's pretty waterproof or at least water resistant Overall, I would buy one of these if you don't already. It will really change how you feel about your teeth and the cleanliness level of them.

  269. I replaced my broken Oral B toothbrush with this one after friends told me Sonicare was better. It's true. The Oral B brush is like a wooden roller coaster: noisy and clackety. It gets the job done, I guess, but crudely. Like brushing your teeth with a jackhammer. Philips Sonicare feels like a professional tool, and my teeth feel cleaner and seem whiter. I love the &#34;Clean & White&#34; cycle, which has an extra 30 seconds at the end (divided into two 15-second intervals) during which to focus on the front top and bottom teeth. And the fact that the brush turns off after the cycle sets a definite limit. You know you've done what the dentist recommends once the brush turns off. Brushing with the Oral B was uncomfortable and stressful, since I felt like my teeth and gums were battered but needed extra brushing to get really clean. The Sonicare, on the other hand, has me looking forward to brushing, since the process is comfortable and efficient. Another plus is that the charger on this model is very compact. I don't want or need a bulky uv sterilizer or storage unit for other brush heads. This charger has a small area on which you may store other heads, but it's unobtrusive. I am so happy with my purchase. I highly recommend the Sonicare HealthyWhite, especially if you're tired of your Oral B.

  280. I had a great dental appointment today. For years, I would brush my teeth (I've always been bad at flossing) but have horrible dental visits. I had numerous cavities and fillings. The hygienist would spend over an hour cleaning and another half hour lecturing me on my poor brushing technique and distinct lack of flossing. One year, the cleaning was so involved (painful) that I left the dentist's office with blood spots all over my shirt.<br /><br />Four years ago I purchased Sonicare toothbrushes for my wife and I. We haven't looked back. I really like the timer feature. I get a good brushing each morning, but still don't floss. I noticed an immediate improvement in my first dental visit six months after starting with Sonicare. It was shorter than usual and less painful. Each year since, it's gotten slightly better.<br /><br />Today I went in for my annual check-up after approximately four years of Sonicare once per day (and still very rarely flossing). I started the appointment at 8:00 AM and left the dentist's office at 8:12 AM. This included x-rays, dentist review, the dentist checking my mouth (and giving kudos), the hygienist doing a cleaning with fluoride treatment, and the hygienist ending the appointment saying \\"Whatever you're doing to take care of your teeth, keep doing it. There was absolutely no buildup. We don't see that much.\\"
  281. This brush is like a power tool for your teeth, and if you want to understand how it compares to a manual toothbrush, it's the same as the difference between a hand drill and an electric drill. It doesn't push articles out from between teeth, it vibrates them out, and if you follow the instructions, holding the brush at a forty-five degree angle on the gum line, the results are way superior to a manual brush. The proof of the pudding: My checkups at the dentist show my gum line actually improving slightly which, at my age, is good news. The brush has a timer for a two-minute tooth-brushing and, since I'm a bit OCD, I keep a clock with a second hand nearby, to make sure I give thirty seconds to each quadrant of my mouth. There is a second speed for tooth brightening, but too many years of tea and coffee drinking have put my teeth beyond the powers of this brush. This feature is overstated by the company. The only problem with the brush is that for best results you need to change the brush head every three months. Three brush heads will run you twenty dollars if you find them on sale. Add that to the initial cost of the brush, and it's considerably more expensive than manual brushing. I think it's worth it, but I was talking to a young person about using an electric toothbrush, and he said, \\"You spend WHAT to brush your teeth!?\\"
  282. What gets me about this is how they have a kind of \\"safety\\" feature, where to turn it off you have to hold the button for like 5 seconds straight. You can just imagine these German engineers working it out. \\"Well, what if a person accidentally pressed the button and the toothbrush turned off? Imagine the damage this could do! Whole teeth could end up unbrushed, and all for nothing, by accident! NO!! We must protect the consumer from this terrible risk! We can put in a 5-second delay to ensure that no one will ever accidentally turn off the toothbrush and interrupt the proper tooth-cleaning process!\\" Anyway, it's an absurd pain in the neck. You are meant to use the toothbrush for the amount of time that the designers have deemed correct, and then it goes off. If you might want to, say, hold it under running water to clean it a bit... well, that's 5 looooong seconds to turn it back on, and then 5 loooooong seconds to turn it back off. Just stupid, really.
  283. I have been going back and forth about buying an electric toothbrush for over a year now. I did a lot of research, and this was the one that seemed to \\"come out on top\\". I received it two days ago - and I am thrilled! I feel like I just came from the dentist each time I use it! The timer is useful -- I never realized how short of a time I used to brush for with a manual toothbrush. I have sensitive teeth (due to exposed dentin from brushing too hard....this toothbrush was what my dentist recommended to stop me from brushing so hard) and I did not experience any pain/discomfort. Definitely 5 stars!

  289. This purchase was my first foray into the world of electronic toothbrushes. There are two brush modes to choose from: a 2 minute clean mode and an additional (optional) 30 second whitening mode. I usually opt for the additional whitening mode. On occasion, I find that my gums are a little sore after using it so when that happens I switch back to a regular toothbrush for a few days. My boyfriend and I share this one using different toothbrush heads with identifying color bands. There are slots to hold two toothbrush heads in addition to the actual toothbrush on the charging station so it could easily store brush heads for three people. Additional heads would have to be stored off of the charging unit if you were buying if for a family of 4 or more.
  290. I'm loving my sonicare. So far no issues and I is pretty quiet. My teeth feel great. The brush heads are easy to order. I was a oral b gal before. I think I've made the switch.
  291. I was a bit late to the electric toothbrush party, and jumped to the cheaper competitor at first. After a few months, I decided to see what all the fuss was about with Sonicare. It is so much better than the competition. You can feel it after the first brush, as if you never knew your mouth could feel so clean. This was the most basic model I could find, and I am very satisfied with it even without all the fancy extras that are available in other models. After a year, there are no signs of it slowing down, even with two people using it twice a day. The number of uses in between charges is impressive as well. If you haven't tried a Sonicare, I highly recommend.

  308. No need to upgrade to this model. I was a very happy Sonicare user for the last 5+ years, so when my last Sonicare died I did not hesitate to replace it with a newer model. Unfortunately, this one is a disappointment. The 'clean' mode works fine, just like my old one. However, the power button toggles between the 'clean' and 'white' mode. It also pauses the toothbrush. Therefore, it's nearly impossible to know what mode you're in prior to brushing and it's difficult to change modes while brushing. Way too much hassle for a toothbrush. Save your money and just go for the basic Sonicare brush.
  309. I previously owned a [[ASIN:B000UK2W4C Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush with Sanitizer]] which includes the UV sanitizer a the travel charger and pouch, and that was destroyed in a kind of dramatic accident. This brush is compatible with everything so I am basically using it as replacement part.<br /><br />This model is half the price, it comes only with the travel charger, only two modes for brushing and the battery power indicator only has one led that starts blinking when charge is below a certain percent.<br /><br />I highly recommend buying the [[ASIN:B000UK2W4C Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush with Sanitizer]], but if you want to expend less money this one does the job.<br /><br />It is basically the same brush, which provides a DEEP and gentle cleaning experience, only that you have two programs, one for standard cleaning and the other(a bit more intense) for whitening. I miss the gum massage program, otherwise this model would be perfect.<br /><br />The simple battery indicator is more than enough as the charge lasts for a complete week of use.
  310. I had the older model - its going by HX5351 these days. Its the one that lets the water (and whatever) down into the handle and leads to mold if not cleaned often. This new design does not allow for that issue and the brush heads cost less. The brush head for this new one just snaps onto a pin. Also, on the whitening mode it is definitely more powerful. The base for charging does seem a bit on the cheap side. There's this plastic piece that fits over the base and it's for holding extra brush heads. Appartently that it is supposed to snap in place. It doesn't seem to want to do that - the tolerances are off enough, here, that it just simply doesn't happen. In any case, it rests over the top without snapping and I don't have anyone else using it besides me - so it's not really an issue. I'm imagining it probably won't last as long as the old model as the parts moving at extreme speeds that were part of the replaceable brush head are now inside the handle. The old handle had no moving parts - just an electromagnet that was alternating polarities rapidly to get the brush head to vibrate - so there wasn't much that could break. My old one has got to be around 10 years old and still works fine. I'm just tired of trying to clean it out regularly due to the poor design and tired of paying more for brush heads. I believe my old one came with an antimicrobial coating inside the handle and it didn't seem to need to be cleaned as often. My girlfriend just bought a new one of the older model (HX5351) that didn't advertise that coating inside the handle (they make them cheaper now to save money). Her's seems to get dirty pretty fast compared to my old model. If you feel like you want to spend 80 on a toothbrush - more like a hundred by the time you buy extra brush heads that you're going to need, then this is the one to get. I don't think I've gotten one new cavity since using Sonicare. However, I did just see 10 Oral-B toothbrushes, shrink-wrapped all together, at Sam's for like 8 bucks.
  311. great toothbrush! My old electric toothbrush was good but only lasted about 2 yrs, over time it started to lose it's oomph, it got slower & slower and i could tell it wasn't cleaning as well. So i bought this electric toothbrush to replace it. I love it, my only gripe is that it automatically shuts off after (2 mins i think it is) has elapsed. My old one would vibrate to let you know, but it would stay on which i prefer. Also, it gave a cute smiley face on the digital screen on the front to show you that you had brushed long enough. I kinda miss that. but i really love how well this toothbrush cleans & that is what i bought it for. My gums feel better and my teeth are squeaky clean. :)

  318. This is my second tooth brush and I decided to go electric after complaints of my dentist saying I brush too hard. I got this one with a coupon on the amazon page and saved $10 right off the bat. The tooth brush came with 1 head, the motorized handle, a stand and the power cord. The tooth brush is really easy to use and very self explanatory. Just charge it, pop a bristle on, press the button and it will activate the time that tells you when to switch quarter every 30 seconds. Do the front and then do the back of the teeth and you are good to go. It leaves a nice tingling sensation that feels good right before bed. The battery seems to last a while. I have used mine for a couple weeks at a time and It hasn't died on me yet.
  319. I needed to replace my old Sonicare that I used for almost 15 years. This new one is just as good or better with a whitening cycle. Only would use Sonicare!
  320. I had an older model sonicare for a few years. Recently the battery on that one died and so I decided to pick up a new one. After doing some pretty in depth research online I came to this model. There are so many pros to this model, and so far after 3 months of use I have seen very few cons. To help illustrate my point of view, I used to have the sonicaire brush where the brush head screwed onto the handle.<br /><br />First of all, this is a much sharper looking brush. That's really sort of useless, but I like that it looks good. The unit has a smaller charger which is great because I travel. It takes up less space on my bathroom counter, and less room in my bag.<br /><br />Another huge improvement is the head type. My old brush constantly grew mold on the inside. I would have to unscrew it and wash it with soap and water weekly. This new design completely alleviates that concern.<br /><br />The pulse timer is also great. If in regular mode, you get 4 pulses at 30 second intervals so you can give the same care to all of your teeth. If you have it in clean mode, you get the 4 pulses, plus you get two additional ones at 15 seconds. That allows you to give your &#34;front visilble&#34; teeth a little more attention.<br /><br />I will say that since I have been a sonicaire owner, my dentist visits have dramatically gone down. I have soft teeth prone to cavities. I used to have around 4 cavities a year filled. I am proud to say that since buying my first sonicaire, I have has NO new cavities form!! It is an absolutely worthwhile investment. That is why I rushed out to replace my old one when it died.<br /><br />While the heads are a little expensive, it's a great investment in your dental future. We all only have one set of the chompers, better take good care of them!
  321. I've owned two generations of Sonicares previous to this one - a first generation basic model way back, and an elite 5500 (?) that got the more natural slanted shaft and got rid of awkward plastic tab behind the brush of the 1st gen. Neither one died on me, both lasted years. From the E-series to the R-series (710), the major upgrades seem to be: -Cheaper, better, simpler and smaller replacement brushes. No longer complicated screw-on affairs, the brushes just get pushed on a vibrating bolt, for lack of a better term. There are a lot less places for disgusting gunk to build up and easier clean up. Take much less time to switch heads, if you have to share them (or if the kids have to). They are slightly cheaper to replace, natural as it seems a lot less complicated design. -Charger base is smaller, same bolt on design as brush head. -Setting for tooth whitening. Wilder pulsing basically. -Sleeker, smaller, more comfortable body. I only moved from the E-series because I orignally bought it as a 2-for-1 special with a family member who eventually moved out and it only came with one base charger. An extra (replacement) one would have cost nearly $45 with shipping + replacement brush head for at least $13, might as well buy a new set at that point. If you have a Sonicare already, it's probably most economical to stay with yours till it dies as none of the features are revolutionary. Still, I probably like the brush head redesign and resulting cleanliness/lack-of-gunk the best.
  322. I received this tooth brush as a replacement. The Customer Service at Sonicare was very efficient and professional. I am very happy with R710 HealthyWhite Power Toothbrush as it cleans my teeth like my dental hygienist without the prohibitive cost. It even reaches and cleans the hard to reach area like my wisdom teeth all the way in the back. There is no going back to old toothbrush as I am so impressed with this toothbrush.

  330. This is a great toothbrush. I ordered the 710 because I thought it was the most toothbrush for the money, and boy was I right. The box contained the handle, one brush head, an a/c charger with clip-on spare brush head holder (holds two), three color rings for identifying brush heads, and instruction/warranty info. Sonicare offers a 2.5 year warranty, and some rebates and coupons in the kit as well. I charged the handle until the battery indicator light went solid green, installed the brush head, and turned the unit on. The 710 is surprisingly powerful, and there are two speeds to choose from. Brushing with the Sonicare tickled at first, but I got used to it quickly. There is a built in timer that beeps every 30 sec. and the unit turns off after two minutes. The whitening mode uses a different vibration frequency and adds another 30 sec. to the two minute cycle. The brush seems to clean very well, it makes my mouth feel cleaner than my old battery powered toothbrush and because it is rechargeable, I don't have to waste money on batteries. Sonicare has more expensive models, but those models only give you more cleaning modes and accessories. This seems to be the same handle and brush that you get with the 129.99 flex-care kit, just without the bells and whistles. If you are looking for good deal on a simple, top-quality sonic toothbrush, look no further.
  331. The product is amazing and price is good. Delivery was also really fast. It was a smooth transaction. I will definitely come back in the future

After reinstallng the brush head several times, I decided it must be defective and tried a second one, with the same problem. For the price of the replacement brush heads, I expected better. I realized there must be a problem with the replacement brush heads, so I contacted Philips to check. The support person told me she was not aware of a problem, and said she was authorized to send me one replacement brush head. I didn't see what good another potentially defective brush head would do, so I declined but went on Philips website and tried to post a review similar to this one to warn people of the potential problem. I received an email reply that my review would not be posted since it did not meet their \\"guidelines\\", which I would assume means that they will not post a review with anything negative about their products. I was disappointed with the defective brush heads (yes, the ones I purchased referenced this model on the packaging and yes, I had replaced them on the previous model several times and replaced them on this model at least once previously, so I knew how to change them) but I am more disappointed in a company that willingly misleads their customers by refusing to post an accurate, legitimate review because it highlights a potential problem with the product.

I do find the HealthyWhite feature a little gimmicky - it just adds another 30 second cycle to the regular 2 minute cleaning, during which you're supposed to focus on your front teeth.<br /><br />My teeth are cleaner now, and hopefully my dentist and I will be happier.<br /><br />12/10/2013 update<br />My toothbrush has started flaking out - it seems to have a bad connection inside. The sonic technology is not abrasive on gums, but is powerful on teeth. The vibration took me a few days to get used to, but after that it was great. I will never go back to a spin brush!

I can't believe that I went this long without one.

I love coffee, blueberries and things that stain your teeth, but I noticed my teeth were whiter within a couple of weeks.

  380. This toothbrush is amazing, easily the best I've owned. I've had problems with staining for a while now, and this really helped prevent and reverse some stains I've had and prevented me from getting them cleaned by the dentist every 3 months.<br /><br />The timer that tells how long to brush each section is probably the best feature. Every 30 seconds, a slight beep tells you to change the brushing area (bottom front, bottom back, top front, top back). I don't really miss any spots and clean my teeth much more thoroughly because of it.<br /><br />The whitening stage is really cool too. It adds two 15-second periods at the end of normal cleaning to focus on the top and bottom front teeth. Definitely gives the extra oomph I need to stay white and fresh.<br /><br />The brush cleans off easily, charges well and even travels well. I couldn't recommend this more.

My previous brush had the magnetic contacts exposed which eventually started falling off, or moving out of position, impacting the performance of the brush, which along with the penetration of water, and difficulty in keeping it clean, reduced its life.<br /><br />This brush design has clearly taken those flaws into consideration and eliminated them.   400. Yep, you read that right. I hate brushing my teeth. Fortunately they tend to stay in good condition between dental visits but my hygienist has been nagging me to get this thing for a year now since I tend to build up plaque easily on some teeth. After she threatened me with visits every four months, I figured I better get it.<br /><br />They say you're supposed to brush your teeth for two minutes. Heck, I'm lucky to pull thirty seconds so I didn't know about the two minute timer thing on the sonicare.<br /><br />But lo and behold, I dig the way this thing feels when &#34;brushing&#34; my teeth. It's like massaging your gums. You don't really brush you just let the thing do its thing and move the bristles back and forth as they instruct you to. Man, that vibrate movement feels good! Two minutes is easily doable and my teeth feel so much cleaner afterwards. I drink a lot of coffee and my front teeth stain quite a bit. Actually, as my hygienist explained, it's the plaque that stains, not so much the enamel. So I'm really looking forward to seeing what this thing can do with the staining issue on have on a couple of front teeth that tend to get a lot of plaque build up.<br /><br />After a week I can already say that I'm glad I made this investment. Afterall, it's a lot cheaper than dental work or having to go to the dentist more often.
  401. I am writing a review for this (we bought this back in June 2013) This is the second Philips Sonicare toothbrush we have been through. Both times the charger quit working just outside of the 2 year warranty. So disappointed. Love the way it cleans our teeth but for the price I wish it would last longer.
  402. Does a great job for keeping up with the periodontal work, making the work of your peridontist only necessary once.
  403. Can't believe how great my smile is when I know my teeth are clean and white. Best tooth brush to use to keep periodontal disease at bay.
  404. When my Rotadent finally gave up the ghost after TWELVE years of service, I was skeptical about changing brands. My dentist recommended the Sonicare very highly, so I decided to give it a try. I LOVE it! It is so much easier to use than a rotating head, and my teeth feel like I've just come from a professional cleaning. I was so impressed the first time I used it!<br /><br />I considered higher-end models, but how many ways do you really need your toothbrush to vibrate? C'mon. This one has two settings, which is plenty in my opinion. The first setting is 2 minutes, and there is an indicator every 30 seconds so you can brush each 'quadrant' of your teeth for equal amounts of time. That sounded a little juvenile to me, but I have found that I really like it. It keeps me from rushing through my brushing.<br /><br />The second 'whitening' setting is 2.5 minutes. The first 2 minutes are just like the first setting, with the indicator, then it does two 15-second segments that have a different vibrations. You are supposed to use those to do your front teeth, top and bottom. I use the first one for my front teeth, and the last 15 seconds for my tongue and palate. Works great!<br /><br />The stand is super easy to use, and I love that the heads have covers and fit on the stand. For the Amazon price, I was able to get two brushes for the price of what I would have paid at the dentist's office - one for my bathroom, and one for the kids. I also ordered a pack of extra heads. Now everyone has their own head, and we share the two handles. We all love it.<br /><br />There are other models with more settings, but, like I said, for the price, this has all you need to brush your teeth. Some models have a sensitive setting, which I leaned toward because I have an area of my gums that gets extremely sore. However, I have not had any problems with this brush irritating my gums, and they have actually been MUCH better since I started using it. I wouldn't pay extra for features you don't need. Save your money for replacement heads, because they aren't cheap.<br /><br />Overall, I'm VERY happy with my purchase!
  405. Lightweight, easy to use, works well. Would be nice to have a place to store the cap. Also would be nice to be able to switch on the whitening mode without having to cycle through the two minute regular mode.
  406. We use to use Oral-B toothbrushes and our dentist recommended that we switch to Sonicare. The difference between the Sonicare and the Oral-B are like the difference between day and night. The Sonicare no only has a harder scrubbing action, it actually forces water between your teeth. My teeth got noticeably whiter within a week of receiving it. It is miles ahead of the Oral-B in cleaning.. getting junk off my teeth that the Oral-B wouldn't touch. Truly miles above the Oral-B (and I was a huge Oral-B fan). One suggestion: I would let the toothbrush do the work.. it is so strong that I fear that it could take enamel off (although I am not a dentist).<br />The best part is that when it died after 25 months, I called Philips and they are actually replacing it for free even though it is well out of warranty. That's what I call customer service!
  407. I am SO happy with Philips as a company because they give superior customer service. I've had my Sonicare for a few years now, and I absolutely love it! After giving them my brush's serial number, they determined it was still under warranty as I registered it when I received it (do this with any of their products!).   413. I have owned this toothbrush for nearly a year with no problems. The nice thing about the lithium battery is you can leave the toothbrush on the charger after each use, similar to a landline telephone. However, I only put the toothbrush on the charger when the battery light flashes, indicating the battery level is below 50 percent. The battery light will flash yellow if it is below 5 (or 10) percent. There is no need to drain the battery before recharging; it can be recharged at any time. There has been no problems with the brush heads. After each use, I remove the brush head to wash the inside and outside. The brush head has never accidentally popped out of the handle. The only thing I do not like is the shape of the bristles. I would have preferred flatter contour. I use to own an inexpensive Oral-B toothbrush with a round brush head. I cannot tell which does a better job of brushing. As long as you brush daily, any toothbrush will do the job. I replaced my 6-years-old Oral-B toothbrush with the Sonicare because of the lithium-ion battery and longer battery life.
  414. My son and I used the Sonicare brushes for years and loved them. I could not believe how clean my teeth were even though I always brushed and believed I was caring for my teeth. Our original units are still going strong (with third set of brushes). When they give out, I will repurchase the Sonicare unit again. FYI: Our units have the pop-on brushes, not the older screw-on brushes.

  453. I've had a Sonicare since they originally hit the market. They last forever. My Elite died after many good years and I replaced it with this one which I think is even better. It took me awhile to decide which one to buy as the choices were overwhelming. I went back to a manual brush in the interim and my teeth never really felt clean. My gums bleed probably secondary to the start of perio disease. After several days of use the bleeding stopped and my teeth felt like I'd just been to the hygentist. At the time I bought this the best price was here. The same goes for the Clarisonic skinbrush. Your skin will never be so clean. Same technology.
  454. It feels better than I thought it would. I've had it for a week and it definitely seems worth the money so far. My teeth feel much cleaner like they do when I get them cleaned at the dentist.
  455. My teeth have never felt so clean. I love the timer one it and the battery is outstanding. It's been my first experience with an electric toothbrush and I wish I had switched long ago.
  456. my first sonicare toothbrush was an elite 1500 series number that i loved from the moment i first used it. it lasted 7 (yes, seven) years; while i tried to \\"settle\\" for something less costly when it at last died, the lure of the great \\"cleanth\\" that is part of the sonicare experience was too great to resist. i even tried my \\"old school\\" regular manual toothbrush....yuck. not clean enough! i read many reviews of the new generation sonicare products, and decided that i would keep it simple and skip the sanitizers and multi-modes offered. the HealthyWhite series is easy to figure out how to use and it works, all the time. it's easy to keep clean, lightweight, relatively quiet, and i'm relieved to no longer have to 'dismantle' the brush head to dry out the inside of the handle... i really like the soft grip feature coupled with an easy-to-hold shape...makes that \\"fingertip grip\\" that is so important w/ sonicare brushes quite simple to maintain. my one regret in life is i didn't take better care of my teeth early on. using my sonicare HealthyWhite makes me feel as if i'm doing the best with what i have, and am making an authentic effort to maintain optimum oral health. best.toothbrush.ever.

All the positive reviews are people who have only been using it for a few months. PLEASE LOOK AT THE 1 STAR REVIEWS. We are not lying- IT WILL BREAK.<br /><br />This is a huge expense to replace every year. I was just on the phone with customer service and they will not replace it because it is 1 month out of warranty- unbelievable. They offered a 15% off coupon for a brand new one. YEAH RIGHT!<br /><br />The problem specifically is that the metal vibrating piece on the main toothbrush is supposed to vibrate back and forth. Now it is completely loose and is free to rotate 360 degrees. So when powered on the toothbrush head just shakes all over the place rather than vibrating the brush bristles for a teeth cleaning. It doesn't clean my teeth anymore and it is going in the trash.<br /><br />AVOID unless you are willing to replace every year.

  471. Dentists over the years always recommended this product to me, but I hesitated to buy it based on the price and the fact that I thought they were just peddling products. At the time, this toothbrush was $150. This fall, I finally decided to take the jump, in a quest for cleaner looking teeth and fresher breath. I was happy to see that the $70 product received just as good reviews as the more expensive one, so I chose that one.<br /><br />I have not been disappointed. It does a very thorough job at cleaning. I like the timer function where it buzzes to let you know to move onto a different quadrant of your mouth. All these years, I mainly focused on the front of my teeth and tops of my molars. I never really thought to brush the back sides of my teeth, and definitely was not doing it for the full 2-3 minutes. This brush really promotes that kind of diligence. Also, it seems to spray water between the teeth, and is very good at getting up plaque deposits. The only thing I don't love is that I never have that clean mouth feel after using it the way I do when I use a regular brush. I think it's because I'm using it so long that the toothpaste wears out and all of the nasties get unlodged. So I just follow-up with mouthwash and am good to go.

  480. I used to own an older Sonicare and had it for 5 yrs. I felt the same about it, nothing cleaned better. This new design is better than the old and holds a charge longer. I would spend the extra money for sure on this new slim design as opposed to the screw on brush head style they still sell. The screw on type heads are almost the same $$ for replacement as the Pro, and it gets really nasty under the screw cap even though it looks clean on the outside. This Pro head style is a bit too small for me, but its purposely designed that way to get to hard to reach areas. Also with the Pro Head, there are no areas that gunk can get trapped under and it pulls on and off in a snap. So the Pro head is far superior. No need to buy there top of the line unit as this unit gives you an identical result, but with less accessories and a couple less bells and whistles you'll never need. It does not have the battery meter but it lasts for 3 weeks fully charged according to the manual. You literally end up with a dental cleaning result after brushing. You can see and feel the difference after just one use. My teeth are whiter and cleaner. I like the Sonicare over the Oral B because the harmonic vibration action also flosses your teeth while cleaning. The Oral-B spins and does not get in between like the Sonicare does. Not to mention I hate flossing. The Oral-B is also much harsher on your teeth and gums and the brush is much stiffer. I have tried both and hated the Oral-b. While I was in limbo researching the different new Sonicare models when my old battery died, I used the Colgate Spin from Sams. Although Colgate is better than a normal brush, it is far inferior to the Sonicare. A night and day difference. 70 bucks and free shipping, can't beat it.

Original review: My dental hygienist was strongly recommending that I buy an electric toothbrush and I finally listened. She suggested a Sonicare because the brush head is smaller. I've used this for several months now and couldn't be happier. The battery lasts several weeks without charging. And the brush gives a subtle sound vibration when the 30 seconds are up for each mouth quadrant. Based on other reviews, I bought an extra set of the soft sensitive brush heads. But the original ones that came with the toothbrush work just fine for me. No issues with water mildew/mold either - I rinse the brush head after each use and air dry on the charger base. Then I rinse the brush body and let it air dry by the bathroom sink. Can't recommend this toothbrush enough! The proof was in the pudding during a recent dental cleaning.

  509. I previously bought a Sonicare model HX6710, which has a slender handle that is easy to maneuver, and a quiet vibration. I bought this HX6711 model (\\"Healthy White\\") not realizing it was so different - its handle is much bulkier and heavier, and harder to maneuver. The vibration seems much stronger, and sends unpleasant vibration through my whole head. The sound is significantly louder. I assume both models have the capability of removing plaque and keeping gums healthy. If that is true, I can't think of a reason anyone would want the HX6711 model. Note that Sonicare's website makes it virtually impossible to discern the differences between models. My model HX6710 is also apparently a \\"Healthy White\\" model (even though it says \\"Clean and White\\" on the handle), so the model number matters. Philips' Sonicare website is extremely and unnecessarily confusing, using the same name (e.g. \\"Healthy White\\") for these two very different models, and listing exactly the same replacement brush heads under several different names and product numbers. This company makes some good products but seems to be trying hard to confuse consumers.

  532. I've used this toothbrush for a week now and I love how clean my teeth are after brushing them. I use the cleaning mode and brush as instructed (30 seconds on upper outer teeth, 30 seconds on upper inner, 30 on lower outer, and 30 on lower inner. there's a slightly tone change in between to remind you to switch section) and it removes tarter and plague. It does take a few days to get used to if you've never used a sonic brush before. It bothers me for a couple of days because the vibration and noise reminds me of dental check out, which I hate. I also love the brush head. Bristles are soft and gentle on gum. And it is small enough to get to the hare-to-reach spot in your mouth such as wisdom teeth area. I've tried electronic brushes before but they all made my gum bleed the first couple days of use since I have super sensitive teeth and gum. But this one did not do that at all. I also like that the brush has a small section of bristles that are deep blue. When the color of blue fades, it means it's time to replace the brush head. I also like the charger. I can put it on my counter top and stand my brush there. I charged it before first use and it took about 2-3 hours to fully charge the brush and I haven't needed to charge again since then. I showed my teeth to my mom after about 3 days of use and she said my teeth look brighter.
  533. After five months of daily use, this toothbrush stopped working and refused to revive. During its short life, I enjoyed super clean teeth and it even toughened up my gums. I won't be ordering this model again, however, as it became obsolete in an unreasonable amount of time.

  536. I have had the Sonicare HealthyWhite toothbrush for a full two years now, and it has worked flawlessly.<br /><br />From a reliability standpoint, it has been completely trouble free. The battery life has been quite good as well, as I usually can go two weeks without needing to charge it.<br /><br />As far as functionality goes, here's what I like:<br /><br />-Built-in timer that gives you a precise two minute brushing session, as well as the ability to add 15 second extra cleaning sessions for your front teeth, top and bottom<br /><br />-Really penetrates the crevices and removes stuck food<br /><br />-Great job at removing stains from teeth, particularly in the back of your teeth, which can sometimes be neglected.<br /><br />-Light and easy to handle<br /><br />_______________________________<br /><br />The only con I would mention is that the brush heads wear out rather quickly and are not exactly cheap to replace. I would recommend the Diamond Clean heads over the Pro Results as they do a better job overall.<br /><br />This product really is worth the investment. You feel like you just left the dentist's office every time you use it. People really should spend the money to take care of their teeth. You only get one set, and dental problems later in life are not worth skimping out and buying a cheap 2 dollar manual toothbrush every other month.<br /><br />Highly recommend this product if you are looking to improve oral hygiene and want a quality device that's reliable and works effectively.

  551. I don't have bad teeth. Actually never had a cavity at all in my life. Usually I have great dental exams with little work for the dentist to do. However, I say your body is your greatest asset and your teeth are very important for the following key reasons:<br /><br />1) Looks - obviously this is a give away, people like great smiles, helps with attraction big time<br />2) Health - sometimes overlooked, not only cavities and bad gums, but plaque build up that may cause you to have other health problems in the mouth<br />3) Financial - no one ever leaves the dental office after a root canal smiling after their wallet is emptied<br /><br />Anyways, my dentist has been recommending me to get an electric toothbrush for a long time even though my teeth are already pretty white and straight, etc. I got this and will not go back to manual unless I have to. This is the one to get. My positives:<br /><br />1) The ease of brushing. No more moving my hand, wrist, arm to brush. Just hold and let it work itself.<br />2) The ease of cleaning. For some reason (maybe how fast it is vibrating) but no toothpaste or food particles build up on the brush like manual ones.<br />3) Charge. I have only charged it once and have been brushing with it 2x a day for almost a month now. Still haven't charged it yet!<br />4) Timer. I like knowing how long to stay in each quadrant. It helps with consistency and knowing you brushed the full amount of time.<br />5) Whitening. I like the 2nd setting which I use always to get that extra 30 seconds of whitening action. My teeth are whiter than ever and they were already white to begin with. I eat pretty clean and rarely drink coffee or tea and never drink soda. So that may be a big reason too.<br />6) Design. Light and no issue with water leaking in and damaging components. I mean don't drop it in the sink or toilet but water can be used to rinse the top half easily with no worries.<br />7) Cost. I got this for $65 total. Great buy.<br />8) Brand. Philips make great shavers and this seems to be that same quality<br /><br />My negatives:<br /><br />1) Size. It could have been a little lighter and narrower so I can get the back of teeth easier.<br />2) Power. I'd like to see if they can make something even more powerful but that might be dangerous haha.<br />3) Cost. I'd like to see the cost of brush heads drop.<br /><br />:o]be that same quality My negatives: 1) Size. I eventually disassembled the toothbrush and found the inside contained water and saw that the electrical parts (including the battery) had been soaked in water for what appeared to be a long time. Being that the toothbrush (any toothbrush) is exposed to water daily, it's not a huge surprise that water found its way inside to the electrical parts, but I was still dissapointed.<br /><br />Even with the two-year failure, I still give the toothbrush four stars. I use the extra time to clean the roof of my mouth and tongue. Sometimes I'll run it again just to go over the front teeth. I rec'd it on 4-9-13 and it said it will run for 3 wks on a charge. I didn't charge it until 05/04/13. The vibration of the brush never decreased, it would just start shutting off during the 2 min. cycle. I had to learn how to brush with my mouth closed more so that the splatter stayed in and not on the mirror. I like that the brush is more like a brush and not a circle. It can fit behind my back teeth so much better. I wish the replacement brushes weren't so expensive. Sure, you think Sonicare is a great deal because they offer a two year warranty, but what's the point if they take their sweet time sending you, or rather, NEVER sending you the replacement part you need? It has been a month now for me and I have contacted them four times for a replacement part. I really don't know what to do at this point to get my replacement handle that is still well within the two year warranty. It's incredibly frustrating, especially since all I seem to get from them are excuses about my order. Is it really uncommon for them to actually fulfill a replacement order under warranty?<br /><br />So, beware, when you get your toothbrush. It may last you two years, or it may last you one year. When it works, it really is great. But if it breaks within your warranty period, expect a really long wait to get anything from them if at all. I'm still trying to get them to send me something, but it's looking a bit hopeless at this point. I'm really upset since the toothbrush and the heads are expensive, yet they are treating a loyal customer this way.

My Healthy White lasted a little less then a year, and I think it just shook itself apart. The head no longer connects properly to the base, so rather then vibrate, the toothbrush just makes a dull buzzing noise. The only disappointment I have is that they do not last longer. Mine just seem to stop after a couple years but it does not hinder me from purchasing again since I am happy with the way it works.
  627. Replaced an old Sonacare toothbrush with the Healthy White and am very happy with it. Holds a charge really well and the slim profile makes it easy to reach every corner of my mouth.
  628. I started using the Philips Sonicare right after a dental cleaning in July. I recently went for my six-months cleaning. The hygienist said that my teeth had less plaque and stain than ever before and the cleaning was done in record time. Since I was using my usual toothpaste and same old twice-a-day brushing, the difference, without a doubt, was the Sonicare. It's kind of a buzzy, wild thing in the mouth at first but I have gotten used to it and will never use anything else.
  629. I'm not a religious flosser so using this toothbrush goes a long way toward making my teeth feel dentist-clean. I love it.
  630. This is the best electric toothbrush! I don't know how I went so long without it! It feels like I just went to the dentist every time I use it! After two uses, I already noticed that my teeth looked whiter. I will save a lot of money with this since I won't have to buy those white-strips anymore! Thank goodness for Sonicare!
  631. My dental hygienist recommended I purchase this since I've acquired dry mouth due to medication I have to take. The only thing I regret is not getting one sooner. The battery lasts longer than I expected. I started out using it once a day and now use it twice daily. Had no idea I was leaving so much &#34;ick&#34; behind after finishing brushing my teeth.   632. I haven't been able to judge the whitening application of this brush; that's not why I bought it. I just wanted a good electric tooth brush.<br />It seems a little better than the Oral B brush I had. Cleans my chops well. The Oral B brush lasted about two years then conked out. Hopefully this PHillips is reliable.
  633. I switched to this toothbrush from my old Braun OralB, which I had been using for years. It is probably an upgrade in some respects, but not as good in others. First of all, it is too expensive, probably because of all the unnecessary stuff it has on it, like the 30-second signal to switch quadrants. Nothing but a gimmick to make you think you're getting something great. A cheap clock in your bathroom with a second hand could do the same thing. And I don't know about you, but I can't go a full two minutes without having to spit, which means you have to shut the brush off and start it again. Also, the brush head is way too big for people with small mouths. It is very hard to maneuver around the inside front teeth. I have to hold it at a 90 degree angle to get the teeth clean along the gum line which, of course, sprays water everywhere. I plan to replace the original brush with the compact heads (again, way too expensive) and see if they are better. The whitening cycle is another gimmick they could do without. Unless your teeth are stained on the outside, no toothbrush is going to make them any whiter. The thing does do a good job of cleaning the outside teeth and is quieter and has more power than the OralB. I do prefer a power brush over a manual one, but I am just not that impressed with this one. It's okay, but nothing to rave about.
  634. I bought two of these for my girlfriend and I. We both love these tooth brushes. They definitely worth the money, and we both agreed we cannot go back to regular tooth brushes.
  635. Pretty nice toothbrush with great vibration, however, I wish the back of the brush wasn't plastic, because it hits my teeth and is kind of unpleasant.
  636. Had I listened to my dentist and periodontist who have been nagging me to get one of these things, I might have avoided gum surgery, gum recession, tooth wear, and a whole lot of problems. This toothbrush is worth every penny. I've used the Oral B round head type in the past, but this type excels. It's a combination of rapid brushing with sonication, which means it's a bit loud in the head due to sound conduction through teeth and bone. It takes a few rounds of use to get used to the sensation. But two minutes gives you a dentist's chair cleaning. I noticed the difference with two days of use. The unit delivers a one-minute cycle broken up into 15 second intervals to ensure sufficient brushing time.<br /><br />The &#34;whitening&#34; feature of the 710 is a nice feature, giving an additional 15 second scrub for the smile. One slight correction: The enclosed directions are not accurate regarding the &#34;Clean/White&#34; mode. It is not 2 minutes plus 30 seconds but 1 minute plus 15 seconds, after which the unit must be restarted. This turns out to be good since a &#34;spit break&#34; is helpful between sides.<br /><br />This unit is a good compromise between cost and excessive &#34;bells and whistles.&#34; It does what you need it to do. The charging base is small and takes up little room on a crowded sink countertop. The base holds two brush heads with color coded rings to make sharing the unit easy.<br /><br />Some people may be deterred by the cost of good electric toothbrush. Look at it this way: It costs as much as one cleaning at the dentist. And you get it twice a day, every day. It's worth every cent.
  637. I have been using this toothbrush for about three weeks now and I like it very much.<br />My teeth feel very smooth and it does a much better job than a normal toothbrush.<br />I think my dental hygienist will be pleased.
  638. I really enjoy using the Philips Sonicare HealthyWhite toothbrush. So far, I haven't really found any negatives, so I'll just list the positives.<br /><br />1. Incredible battery life! At first I was charging the toothbrush weekly, as was recommended by the manufacturer. Then, I forgot to put it on the charger, and a week turned into two, and it still worked great! There is a battery indicator light that I check each time I brush, and it has stayed solid green (it blinks when it's low) for nearly three weeks now.<br /><br />2. The timer and Quadpacer are so useful! The toothbrush not only times brushing for 2 minutes, it also helps me get each area of my mouth clean by dividing the mouth into four quadrants (inside top teeth, inside bottom, outside top, outside bottom) and indicates when to move on. This seems so basic and I really didn't think I would need it, but I definitely brush more thoroughly with it.<br /><br />3. Overall, this is just a really comfortable brush. I like that it ramped up the power when I first started using it, because the vibrating motion was jarring at first. The brush head is very small and took some getting used to, but I really do like this toothbrush, and I feel like my teeth are much cleaner after having used it.

  645. The model I have has a Clean and White mode that is to brush for two minutes and then a change in sound and motion is to be the signal to start brushing the upper front teeth, At the sound of a beep, you are to brush the lower front teeth. However, I do not sense a change in brushing sound or motion in the first phase nor do I hear a beep to start the second phase. Very disappointed with this issue.<br /><br />Having said that, I am pleased with the product overall. The brush head will stop brushing when it senses too much pressure being applied to the teeth. I tend to brush hard (resulting in receding gums) so this feature is very important to me. The true test will be when I visit the dentist in four months or so.
  646. Awsome brush, almost 4 years strong. BUT, For those of you with the vibrating portion coming loose, I laugh when I see those reviews. Google it, and it's an easy fix. Easy to take apart . The screw that comes loose is a eye glass size phillips head screw. I've tightened mine twice. The best thing to do is put some lock tight on the screw, witch I haven't done yet.
  647. I should have looked at this in a store before purchasing it. I was pretty surprised at how small the brush heads are.   654. When choosing a Sonicare toothbrush, I was looking for something without a lot of bells and whistles that was easy to use (and clean) - this fit the bill perfectly.<br /><br />1. The ProResults brush head is a great improvement over the old brush heads that collected gunk. Just snap off, wipe, and snap back on, that's it.<br /><br />2. I really like the 30 second beeps for each quadrant of the mouth - not a dealbreaker obviously but convenient to have.<br /><br />3. The brush has a second mode for &#34;whitening&#34; that is more powerful but to be honest, I haven't used it more than once or twice because the &#34;normal&#34; mode works just fine IMO. I admit one of the reasons I considered this was because I'm allergic to whatever they put in the whitening toothpastes and this was a non-chemical way to whiten. I think it does a great job even without the whitening mode.<br /><br />4. Travel charger is convenient (pops out of the base), though the base is so small I doubt it makes that much difference.<br /><br />5. Battery life has been great so far (about 7 months) - I charge when the little green light is blinking, maybe once every 2-3 weeks. Honestly if I'm going on a trip for 3-4 days I don't even bring the charger.<br /><br />6. Most importantly, my teeth look and feel great! My dentist recommended an electric toothbrush because I was brushing too hard and I'm really glad I made the switch. Definitely worth it.<br /><br />Just a tip, registering your product on the Philips website extends the warranty, always a good thing.

  664. On the recommendation of my dentist, I've used a Sonicare toothbrush for years. My original Sonicare works fine but is so old that it is difficult to find replacement brush heads for it. I couldn't find them locally, and amazon's price for two was $65. !?!<br /><br />So, I decided to just buy a new Sonicare instead, at $70 for this model. Because many new appliances aren't nearly as well made as the old ones they replace (in my experience), I was somewhat dreading using my new Sonicare for the first time. I was afraid that the new one with the simpler brush head might not work as well as the original models. (Why would Sonicare have made such a complicated brush head if it wasn't necessary?) Wow, I was so pleased to find that the new one is fantastic! The brushing action seems the same as the original, but my teeth feel much cleaner with the new one. I also think my teeth are a little whiter after using it only a few days. In fairness to my old Sonicare, it still works but the brush head is almost worn down to a nub, which I'm sure has lessened its effectiveness. The different design of the new model should prevent toothpaste and gunk from getting into the handle, which was a flaw of the old one. Also, the replacement brush heads for the new model are much less expensive. I charged it for 24 hours before using it, and haven't had it long enough to comment on how long the battery holds a charge. If it's even close to the battery performance of my old one, that won't be an issue. I like the features of this model--useful without a lot of bells and whistles, and amazon's price is good.<br /><br />If you are on the fence about buying a Sonicare, go ahead and buy one! It's a great toothbrush and much less expensive than dental work.

  705. My wife and I went with the Sonicare to replace an Oral B electric toothbrush whose battery finally gave up the ghost.<br /><br />Our experiences thus far:<br /><br />Initially, my wife HATED it. She said she preferred the sensation and mechanics of the Oral B, and started bugging me about getting her another one of that brand. But she continued to give the Sonicare a chance, and at about the 10-day point, said she now preferred the new toothbrush. She says her teeth FEEL about as clean as they did with the Oral B, and that they LOOK whiter.<br /><br />I was more open-minded about the Sonicare from the get-go. I have extremely sensitive gums, and as much care as I took to brush with the Oral B, I occasionally found the rotating head chewing up my gum-line -- to the extent that I would occasionally have to stop brushing a sore area for a few days to allow it to heal. There seems to be no such possibility of that type of damage to gums with the Sonicare mechanism -- it simply uses a less abrasive method. Also, from a purely subjective standpoint, I concur with my wife that my teeth look a bit whiter after brushing with the Sonicare.<br /><br />One thing I note from other reviewers is the greater potential for mechanical failure with the Sonicare (the Oral B's last for as long as the battery holds out). Since we've only had ours for about a month, I can't speak to that issue. I will update my review if I do have any negative experiences in that regard (knocking on wood!).<br /><br />Also -- again, since we've only had the Sonicare for a month -- I can't speak yet to how our future dental check-ups will go. I'll also update the review based on that, if necessary. At least for now, I must say that my teeth certainly feel AT LEAST as clean as they did when I was using the Oral B, and my gums feel significantly less abused.
  706. I was holding out on buying one of these because I thought it would be so cumbersome just to brush. I know this is supposed to help with brushing correctly by cleaning your teeth and being gentle on your gums. I am so glad I finally got this, I love brushing now and feel that my teeth get so clean. It is like coming home from the dentist clean except you can have this everyday!

It's a good thing it takes 14 brushings on the &#34;cleaning&#34; mode to gradually build up to full force! It sometimes makes me dizzy when I'm brushing, due to the vibration of the fluid in my ear, but that's a small price to pay for what this thing does! I've been overdue for a teeth cleaning, so I had some pretty nasty tartar build-up on the inside of my bottom teeth. After just 3-4 cleanings, the tartar was almost completely removed, other than a very slight area between just a couple of my teeth. Also, I do believe it is helping to whiten my teeth. I would recommend this toothbrush to anyone who wants to maintain their dental hygeine between dentist visits! Now, when I go to the dentist this week for my cleaning, I won't feel embarrassed about my tartar situation. Great product! The only thing I don't like is the fact that everything in the bathroom gets splattered while brushing now because of this things power. I'm trying to keep my mouth closed while brushing to eliminate some of that...just a new learning curve well-worth the effort.

Teeth cleaned by this Sonicare still felt reasonably clean just before bedtime when I had to brush my teeth again.<br /><br />The extra 30 seconds for teeth whitening is a good measure to get your teeth extra clean on the front, which easily starts to grow plaque along the gumline by day's end. Like others, I wish it would start up again in the same mode come next brushing session, but pressing the button twice for teeth whitening mode every time is no big complaint.<br /><br />The unit comes with the Pro brush head. The replacement heads I purchased were the DiamondClean variety. Both give a good brushing, but my gums seem to feel like it gets a better massage with the Pro head, as well as gets between teeth easier.<br /><br />I can't compare this to the other units since this is my very first electric toothbrush, but I think this modelhas the best bang for the buck since you can easily find it for less than a hundred bucks. Happy I made the switch over and excited what the new models will be like in 5 years when I need to shop for another unit.

I know that this is common with these toothbrushes, and it's disturbing that the company (and their customers) are OK with this type of waste and poor products.   790. Stopped charging after 25 months of use. The Philips warranty lasts 24 months. Quite the coincidence.
  791. My dentist recommended a sonicare toothbrush at my last checkup, and at first I was skeptical when I saw how expensive they were, but wow this is completely worth all the money I spent! I can't imagine wasting my time using a regular toothbrush again. The timer is also really nice out gives notifications of 30 second interval so you spend the correct amount of time on each quadrant of your mouth. I also love the easily changeable heads, my boyfriend and I both share the same base and the heads are easy to switch and store neatly on the base. Overall if you're like me and are on the fence over the price I say go for it, this toothbrush is worth every penny.
  792. All four gift recipients liked their new toothbrushes. None of us had used an electric toothbrush before but they really do make your teeth look and feel cleaner. You just need to learn not to open your mouth when brushing! I would definitely recommend this particular one. Only complaint was that it didn't come with a travel type cover and it only had one head, despite the packaging having a slot for two heads. Shop around, I got it for $70 but saw it as high as $115.
  793. A very good toothbrush. Wished that it would last a bit longer. Head motor lasts about four years. Will purchase two more.
  794. I was skeptical about buying one of these, however I love it. It really does a nice job cleaning my teeth. It comes with a warranty, so I hope if anything does happen, it happens while its still covered. If not, no big loss. Things aren't meant to last anymore.

  798. I like the feel of this toothbrush, it feels like a good quality product. The biggest problem, for me, is the fact that you have to press and hold the stupid button down for two seconds every time you want to turn it off! This is just stupid. I turn my toothbrush on & off a total of three times during the course of each brushing. Once to spit out all the excess foam that quickly accumulates in my mouth. A second time when I'm finished brushing. And then a third time after I rinse the brush head off in the sink. Well this is now not nearly as easy as it should be, since every time I want to turn it off I have to do the stupid press-and-hold waiting game. This might not be THAT big of a deal, but I'm concerned this is going to eventually wear the button out from having to hold it down so much...my last Sonicare died because the green rubber button tore open allowing water to seep in. And that model didn't even require the 2-second hold! WHY SONICARE??? Why would you do that? Honestly, had I known about this before purchasing and using the thing I probably would have gone for an Oral-B instead. It bothers/concerns me that much.
  799. It gets my teeth clean with very little effort, I highly recommend it to anyone. Compared to other electric toothbrushes I've used before this product performs amazingly well.

The rep I contacted (got through immediately) was very courteous, asked a few usage questions, and then shipped a replacement while I was on the phone - asking me to send the old one in once I got the new one.   875. I bought this when the battery in my old Essence model finally died after 7 years. I did a lot of comparing the different models and chose this one because I didn't care about any of the extra features in the more expensive offerings. (in a way, you've got to feel sorry for the Sonicare marketeers - trying to differentiate an entire product line for a toothbrush. Holy cow! It's a toothbrush! Guess what, they all brush teeth. Anyway...) I like this one better than the old model I had:<br />A) it actually seems to clean my teeth better. I think Sonicare may have a new generation of brushes.<br />B) the brush attachment is simpler and way easier to clean. Instead of the old hard-to-clean giant plastic nut with all the threads to catch and grow dental micro-organisms, there's just a metal shaft to plug into a small socket. Quick and easy to rinse.<br />C) likewise, the body no longer has the matching threads or that deep well and is much easier to keep clean.<br />D) both brush and body are easier to store in the medicine cabinet. Before I used the brush holder that was in a pack of two replacement brushes on top of a lid from pringles can to catch the run-off. I threw all that away and they just sit on the shelf now.<br /><br />I'm entirely satisfied.<br /><br />I can't help you compare to any of the other contemporary models since this is the only new one I bought and I plan to keep it until it dies like its predecessor.

  886. As many others have commented, I too have had problems with this toothbrush, BUT I liked it so much, I bought another one anyway. When I got it in the mail, I noticed an important improvement: over the rubber gasket where the brush connects to the handle they have added a hard piece of plastic that was not there on my last brush. I too had problems where the rubber gasket fell apart after about 2-3 years causing the toothbrush motor to stop working. The rubber gasket is still there though, so here is the key recommendation to preventing it from mil dewing away: remove the brush head at least overnight, if not after each brushing. That should help. For those that had problems with the battery, I never had this. But like any lithium battery, don't keep it on the charger all the time (or at least don't keep it plugged in all the time). I have had 4 Sonicares and never experienced your problem because I always did this. Now, after the first 8 years of using the Advance, yes, the battery would only last 5-7 days, but after a full charge, I always unplug the charger and wait till the battery is about dead before charging it again. Good luck, this is definitely a great toothbrush and with a little extra precaution I am hoping it will last well past the 3 years my last one did. I give it 4 stars because I do have to take the extra precaution. BUT, it is as quite as ever, even with the extra plastic and after 2 days of brushing with a normal toothbrush, I am SO happy to feel that Sonicare fresh feeling again.<br /><br />I remember when I first started using it, my dentist noted immediately that I was doing something different. Teeth were cleaner, had less plaque if any at all, fewer, if any, cavities and my gum pockets were all within the good range. This brush has definitely been a great investment!!!
  887. My dentist said to switch to the Oral B regular handle with Floss Action heads (most important thing) and he was right. Much cheaper and they clean better- you can feel it. I also like how they don't turn off after 2 minutes like all Sonicare brushes do- OralB also has quadpacer but stays on until you turn it off manually. My OralB $29 handle didn't last as long but these Sonicares go out every 2 years like clockwork. Again, I go slower and take longer than the 2 minutes but I've had 2 of the most expensive Sonicare models (3 mode flexcare) and this cheaper $90 handle- none lasted longer than 2 years. The batter doesn't last as long between charges on the OralB and they're a little bulkier. Floss Action heads on any OralB brush beats Sonicare IMO and my dentist says less tarter buildup when I go in for cleanings! I didn't notice any of the 4 different models (2 Sonicare and 2 OralB) making a difference in cleaning or whiting compared to cheaper model/same brand. Bleaching your teeth white is bad people!
  888. I have been thinking about getting a sonic care toothbrush for embarrassingly, years! and I finally broke down and bought one because this is a really good deal; value for the money spent.<br /><br />It does an excellent job of cleaning my teeth and keeping them white. They feel so clean, it is like I have been to the dentist for a cleaning.<br /><br />If clean teeth are important to you, buy this toothbrush.
  889. Been using these for over 15 years and my dentist is very pleased with my results. I find that they last longer if I charge only when needed. A few years ago I remarried. My wife was using a different brand that required charging every other day. I bought her a Sonicare and she was amazed at the improvement in brushing and her dentist has also noticed a difference. We brush twice a day with the Sonicare and only recharge every three to four weeks.
  890. I really like the Sonicare rechargeable toothbrush. It works very well, and my teeth feel so clean after use. I would recommend this product.
  891. The only reason I did not give 5 stars is this product lasted exactly 3 years. I would have liked if it lasted at least 5 years. The warranty is only for 2 years.
  892. This is my second philips sonicare rechargeable toothbrush. The only reason I bought a new one was that after 10years of everyday use, the old one died. This one is more powerful and a narrower hand grip. The narrow hand grip is nice for me--much easier to hang onto as you are manipulating over the differant areas in your mouth. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend any of the sonicare products----just pick the right one for you and your family.
  893. I have had Sonicare products for a few years and as you'll see in a simple Internet search, the products have gotten cheaper and cheaper. Now the batteries only last a few months and can not be replaced. Never again for this product!
  894. It works really well, and my teeth feel cleaner longer.<br /><br />I would like to have had a travel carry case for it though.
  895. It cleans like a hygienist would and definitely helps to whiten. I'll never use anything else.<br />Anyone can benefit from this products. It's a winner.
  896. I am used to the previous E model that I liked very much. This one seems fragile, but it does a good job so far.
  897. I love this sonic toothbrush. It replaced a previous one I had that had stop working after 5 years. This is an upgraded to that one and it is awesome.
  898. The design and operation of this toothbrush is excellent. I just wish it was reliable. What has consistently happened is that after 6-10 months the toothbrush begins to operate erratically, then not at all. Actually, it is funny. The first sign of failure frequently came when the toothbrush would suddenly turn itself on with no one around it. I would hear this funny vibration-like noise coming from the bathroom and find it operating on its own. Or it would not respond to the power button when I wanted to turn it off. All the failure modes were the same: the electric control circuit would fail, most likely because water would seep into the handle and short it out.<br /><br />I called Philips Sonicare customer service each time and they have been excellent in their response, replacing tooth brushes under warranty without any hassle. I love the product but just couldn't keep it operational despite taking care not to get the handle too wet (which is almost impossible to do since toothpaste residue builds up on the face where the removable brush attaches and it needs to be cleaned off).<br /><br />I have given up on this model and have switched to the (less expensive) Essence design, which I also like but haven't used long enough to comment on my experience with its reliability.
  899. I had a sonicare toothbrush and liked it very much but it was wearing out after many years of service. I wanted a new one that beeped every thirty seconds and did a better job. I am very happy with it, my teeth are whiter and smoother with this brush. Yes, I would recommend the Sonicare to anyone that asks.
  900. This tooth brush is amazing!! It works so well and it was worth the money.. I also saw the same tooth brush at target and realized that I got mine 20 bucks cheaper! Very happy!
  901. This was my first electric toothbrush and I bought it because of the positive reviews. It didn't disappoint; this toothbrush is slim, light and easy to keep clean. The only minor downside is having to press the power button twice to get to the &#34;Clean and White&#34; function, which I feel should just be the default. Other than that - it's great. Would recommend to anyone.
  902. My teeth have never felt so clean!!! Brushing with a regular toothbrush is for the birds! I'm looking forward to my next dentist's visit because now I have been able to brush my teeth at the suggested 45 degree angle effectively and my teeth and gum line feel and look great. A great product at a great price with a coupons for more products too (the replacement heads and the flosser).
  903. Nice, simple toothbrush. Highly recommend. Had one with all the bells and whistles - none of which I ever used - so went back to the simple one - very happy.
  904. So far so good. TaKes getting used to, as it really vibrates<br />Your teeth. But you will enjoy it as you use it.
  905. Purchased this for my husband and he loves it. I already had one of my own and he kept trying to steal it so I purchased him one so he would keep away from mine. We both have better dental checkups since we started to use this, awesome product.
